Dont expect to get timely or in depth feedback on assignments or answers to the homework. This class failed to adjust when many students had to take on extra responsibility at home

Sandeep knows his stuff. He is a good lecturer, but his tests are extremely difficult - way beyond the scope of a 100 level CS class in my opinion. He is a very strict grader for all assignments, hw, tests, etc.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Bhatt is the worst professor I have ever seen in Stevens. His lecture is neither helpful nor inspirational. F to this professor.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Sandeep is a great lecturer and knows his stuff without question. Unfortunately, he never found a grading scheme (a pun!) that worked. He refused to own responsibility for (classwide) grading fiascos. CS 135 was not spectacular, but certainly manageable. Psets test you well, labs are a loose component that don't, and QF semesters suck.
Sandeep gets a bad reputation for his class being hard, but it's really the material and not him. You have to put in work and go to office hours and you'll do fine. 135 is much harder than 334.

He gets a lot of flack because he teaches some of the hardest classes in CS and makes sure his tests/homework reflect that, but he's genuinely one of the best lecturers I've had. He explains very well and is more than happy to take a whole class answering questions. The man clearly knows a lot and it shows.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Sandeep gets a lot of flack because he's the only professor teaching some of the most infamously difficult CS classes. He does a good job with the things that he teaches. Just do the work he gives you, pay attention in lecture, and go to office hours, you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Sandeep gets a lot of hate because his classes are difficult. I myself, did poorly in CS135 because I simply didn't put in the effort. His explanations aren't perfect but he does a decent job. He is also pretty helpful at office hours. He makes the homeworks and tests for CS135 pretty hard, but there is a curve.

Sandeep gets a lot of hate because he teaches a difficult class which most CS majors aren't used to. The material is hard itself since it deals with some pretty abstract math, but Sandeep himself is very understanding and tries to get you a good grade. Sandeep is always available to help and takes feedback well. Also the class is very curved 75B

One of the worst professors I've ever had in my life, you would even think that office hours would help too, but NOPE even the TA's don't know what they are doing. The textbook given to us online is elementary school problems compared to the cancer they give out in problem sets and actual quizzes. Good luck whoever is reading this you'll need it.

Sandeep gets a lot of negative feedback because of the difficulty of his classes, but you can learn a lot when you put the effort in. There are plenty of resources available outside of class to help you learn the material, and he is always willing to help during his frequent office hours.

He's a nice person, but as a professor, not so much. I can safely say that I left this class knowing absolutely nothing, just grateful that I passed it. There really is no clear grading scale, and your final grade was a surprise.

Students dislike Sandeep because he makes them participate in actual learning as opposed to memorization, which is all the work most Stevens students are used to doing. The class isn't hard because, although getting 90's is very difficult, an average of a 75+ is an A-. So if you do ALL the hw, attend lectures, and review before tests, you will pass
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Easily one of the worst classes I have ever taken. The homeworks are virtually impossible. The quizzes are incredibly difficult to prepare for. A memorable quote from the man himself, "What looks like a failing grade, might not be a failing grade". Avoid at all cost.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Tests are tough

comment: Horrible. Horrible. Horrible
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Sandeep isn't all bad. It's obvious that he cares about our learning and wants us to do well, he's just terrible at lecturing. Going to his office hours with specific issues can yield better results, but get ready to teach yourself most of the material. Instead of explaining concepts he just shows tangentially related proofs and seems as lost as us
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Sandeep gives disproportionately hard quizzes when compared to the homework and lecture examples. He explains concepts during lecture with examples, and then his homeworks and quizzes are absolutely ridiculous. He is a tough grader and does not understand that if students are failing quizzes consistently, something needs to change.
Best professor I've ever had

Its unfortunate that he's such a nice guy. His lectures go on a thousand tangents and are usually a lot of theorems with little explanation. In class examples are usually complicated, but nothing compared to what appears on the tests. Take with engling.

sandeep's 135 is one of the worst experiences of my life. his lectures are very off topic, the homework is really hard, the quizzes can be downright impossible. half of what he does isn't even discrete structures, but probstats or high level discrete math. do yourself a favor and take this with someone like srini or engling.
He's just completely awful

As a professional returning to school after 20 years, it was great to take a focused class without a lot of group work.  He has ample code walkthroughs and very long lectures that he refers to as blogs.  Some of the quiz content is paraphrased, so having at least an understanding of where to look in the material for answers is critical.

He is an alright professor but the nature of this course is fast-paced. Was using an old machine and had to transfer to a newer machine in order to run some of the heavy coding needed for Android Studio, not very accommodating of that for the first few assignments. Not a bad guy, but a rigorous course and isn't really accommodating.

Professor Duggan forces you to reach your limits and really learn the material.  He really cares about sending his students out into the professional world, knowing what they are doing.  Stay on top of the assignments.  Review all of the lecture materials.  Keep plugging away at the programming. When you're not getting it, calm down and keep trying
Generally rude and not very helpful
Good course but only if you have prior experience and knowledge in the field.

He is the worst! The assignment code is a total mess, with tons of bugs right from the start. Plus, he ignores his own grading rules from the syllabus. His lecture notes are confusing, and the videos are either too long or too short. It's a real struggle to keep up. Total disaster!

Where to begin, every assignment was unreasonably long, lecture videos do not communicate material very well and a lot of course content was unavailable or broken. Avoid this course, and honestly this professor in general. Stack exchange is a better resource than the actual lecture material.
If you really Want to Learn Android Development Using Java Take this Course But before Taking the Be ready With all the Concepts Related to Java.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: my primary goal is toacquire knowledge and learn the necessary skills to excel in my field. However, it appears that this professor's mindset does not align with this goal. Rather than encouraging students to learn, he seems to place a significant emphasis on prior knowledge and mastery of the subject matter before allowing attendance in his class.
awful experience

He is the worst professor! im an international student, I never thought I would go through something like this. NOT UNDERSTANDING AT ALL.Long boring lectures, did not consider late submissions&cut marks, gave 0s even when we did not copy anything, college did not allow W. This is the worst experience ever! 3/14 students failed, dont ever opt this
His lectures weren't actually that helpful and I did most of the assignments (weekly code) using outside sources and going to the TAs for help.

This guy has the WebCampus format nailed down. Assignments are reasonable and he stays in touch over Slack about any issues that come up. Late policy is absolutely golden. Some banging your head against the wall during the assignments is to be expected as it is for any application-driven class. Just follow the //TODO's in the stub. Set aside time.

The course is really informative and you actually get to learn proper android app development skills, but you need to spend ALOTTT of time going through his podcasts and doing assignments that you cannot start last minute as they need a thorough understanding. He spends most of the lecture discussing assignments so all hail podcasts.

He is VERY knowledgeable and a MASTER in the field of distributed systems, but that doesn't always translate to being a good teacher. You cannot half-@ss his course. Be ready to learn. What he teaches is what you'll undoubtedly encounter at Senior-level (Manager I equivalent) software engineering positions... a bit too advanced for L3 and L4.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: He is the worst professor I have ever met. DON'T EVER TAKE A COURSE IF HE IS THE INSTRUCTOR. He never acknowledges the effort taken by students and is very harsh even in his comments.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Never reply email. Lots of boring podcasts. Too many homework. Just waste of time.

Its like this was the first year he taught this course and we were responsible for working out all the kinks. Year after year he doesn't fix issues with the assignments or lectures, causing us to hit the same road blocks. He is almost never available for help, and says he responds to emails or Piazza posts but never does! Lots of false promises!!!

It may not have been so bad if the materials were actually properly prepared. Often the material had broken links / missing videos. The biggest issue was the lecture audio and video were not in sync, requiring you to constantly pause or look at the PDF on the side to stay in sync. Several students reported this to him, but he did nothing about it.

Get ready to work! Each week you need to watch hours of lecture, read papers that are 30+ pages, take a quiz, + work on a bi-weekly assignment. This class consumed just about every free minute I had during the week. The quizzes ask for micro specifics that would be difficult for anyone to answer given we were just introduced to the concept.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Hilarious

comment: This is THE worst class at Stevens. It froze over in 2009 as all the lectures were recorded then and haven't been touched since. His stub code is years old and contains many bugs/errors that will trip you up. He hasn't touched the materials in years, and often needs to refresh his memory when asked questions. He can't be bothered to help! AVOID!!!!

You actually will learn a lot in his class, and Prof. Duggan is a good teacher. But it's simply not worth it to take this class! Some of the homework assignments (given weekly) take up to 15 hours to complete. If you finish an assignment within 10 hours you'll probably feel good about yourself. Save yourself a lot of anxiety and frustration. Avoid!

Poor teaching skills! Lectures are heavy and overwhelming. Take his classes only if you have some experience, ready to work very hard and have less workload from other courses. It will benefit you as you have to troubleshoot the assignment's issues by yourself without any help. This course will make you a better Engineer.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: This class was awful. He didn't teach anything relevant to the homework after the 4th week, but there were 9 assignments. He would supply code stubs that had multiple errors in them, some fatal errors that would prevent your code from working. Never answers his email and doesn't respond on Piazza even though he says he does.

This class is possibly the worst class I've taken in my academic career. All of the projects are severely outdated; you'll spend more time debugging the prof's code than your own. The grading criteria is somehow unclear even WITH the rubrics he supplies. The lecture videos are impossible to stay awake to and have nothing to do with the assignments.
DO NOT LISTEN TO ANYONE, YOU WILL REGRET TAKING THIS CLASS.

I don't know why people give him bad reviews. He is one of the best professors at Stevens. I didn't take CS522, but I took CS548 and CS589 and they both are fantastic. The professor is very knowledgeable and his lectures covers a lot of topic in good details. Yes it is a lot of work and yes some codes are outdated, but we see this everyday at work.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures--Lecture heavy

comment: Don't take this course to actually learn Android; its incredibly out of date. His slides show Android from 10 years ago, and half the apis he talks about are deprecated. It's honestly shameful that Stevens even offers this course. The lectures themselves are extremely long and boring and the there's a fairly long hw assignment every week

-> We had 12 quizzes for the 14-week class, its like a quiz every week. You are supposed to attend the lecture, read 150 slides, 2 hours of podcast and papers for a single quiz. -> Professor always seems to be in a hurry for doubt clarifications after class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Hilarious

comment: There is not enough learning materials provided, at the end of the class you will never end up learning a andriod programmer unless you take some other courses outside. His quiz grading awful, expects whatever he told in the class to be put as answers and doesn't accept outside answers!!

Tough class but not graded harshly. Very practical. Knowledge and skills immediately transferred to working environment (software engineer). Some of the provided code has bugs, mostly from aging -- but hey, welcome to enterprise software development. Expect 10-15 hours of work a week, 20+ if you're not a competent developer.
Worst class from stevens. i rather have just taken UDACITY android class and just save my money and time and get certificate.

This will be a hard challenge. Assignments will take atleast 15 hrs of your time per week. Grading criteria is good. Gives A to people above 93, A- to people in between 88 and 92.  Don't take this class if you don't have a clue about android programming or if you have a wooden pc like i5 and 4gb ram cause android studio sucks for those.

Avoid this professor at all costs. Seriously, don't even think about it. The homeworks are extremely time consuming mostly due to the fact that the boilerplate code you have to work from is garbage. You have to watch hours of painfully boring podcasts each week. If you want your sanity, skip this guy.
Classes are way to hard and assignments can take upwards of 20 hours a week. Do not take any of their classes if you want to do well in your other classes.
So much coding assignments and very hard quizes
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I learned a lot in this class, but it was extremely demanding and ran at a break-neck pace. Combined with frequent ambiguity, contradictions, and outright wrong information in assignments, I spent an average of 15 hours per week on this class alone and barely retained anything. Over three-quarters of the class dropped by the end of the semester.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He wrote different definitions about same concepts (covariant and contravariant change in data contract) in two courses CS526 and CS548. He misconceived these two definitions. The code was buggy. Time consuming with more than 5 hours of podcast to listen everyweek. So unless you are serious, audit but not attend.
boring class, too many meaningless homework assignment, you have to do the same coding for about 2 or 3 times.

Tough engineering class only for serious students.  It is up to you to dig deep into the work, research how, and ask questions when needed.  Podcasts galore, all valuable and relevant to the domain.  Teaches you about SOA, REST, xml, bmpn, owl.  You are expected to know Java at a beginner to mid level and be ready to use EclipseJava EE.

You get what you put into it. Homework (programming) was incredibly relevant, used modern technologies, and improved my knowledge greatly.   Homework was time consuming  but the journey was worth it - the same problem solving skills are needed in the real world. Lecture material was great and quizzes were direct from the material, no surprises.

For your own goodness, audit his class but don't go to his class unless you know and master java RMI REST and everything he's going to teach, otherwise you'll get F. He expect students to program stand alone DHT and FTP using RMI, REST or something you may never heard before.

Great professor, tries his best to impart as much knowledge as possible. Take his course only if you are willing to learn and that to in a short span time. The study material is enormous and lot of assignments, so only those who are serious about studying should go for it. Not your usual introduction courses, excellent for masters students.

One of my favorite Professors. I took all his classes because you know what you're going to get.  Slides are relevant to modern technologies.  Homework is too.  Hard?  Yes.  But what isn't that is worthwhile?  His coursework has made me a better and more knowledgeable sw engineer and it is apparent at work.
Almost every assignment has code that doesn't work. Doesn't describe how to do assignments.

Too much work, not worth the effort. Forgets to put up assignments and quizzes and then once he has the time to do so, groups them together. HOURS of podcasts needs to be listened to...which are not interesting, helpful, or insightful. multiple quizzes for some weeks. Not responsive or active in his forums. Buggy /unclear assignment code. Avoid!

My only piece of advice is to just stay away from this guy. If you want to learn pick any other professor. Honestly, you learn nothing in his lectures. He doesn't know why boolean functions return true or false, and he gives you assignments with buggy code. (Aka Buggan) You're better off just teaching yourself.

Horrible. He covers little content during class then puts about 3+ hours of podcasts that must be covered. Not to mention the 3+ hours of podcasts per assignment which have little to no clarity. He's very unclear in assignments and quizzes and often second guesses himself in the middle of lecture.

Had him for operating systems. Never was able to explain anything clearly. If you asked him questions he'd get annoyed. No one in the class liked him. Purposely would make lessons overly difficult. This guy wouldn't be able to explain how to make ice. Should not be teaching. Dislikes helping anyone.

One of the worst professors I have ever had.  Absolutely no regard for students, his stated intention was to fail all students in the class (trying to get the school to drop the course).  Would flash slides on the screen for one second, then test that exact slide.  Avoid if possible.
The professor is not too tough since he curved the grades

This is a difficult course, for final project professor asked us to implement a research paper. Make sure you start working on the project as early as possible otherwise it will be very difficult to finish the project. 
No, you won't be able to finish the project by starting it a day before the presentation.

Fantastic guy and great teacher. I took this as an undergraduate and enjoyed it. Grades are hard to keep up since there are only 2 homeworks, 2 quizes, midterm, and final all of which are graded really strictly, but I blame the TAs more than prof. I'd recommend, but take 442 (undergrad version) if you can.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Professor Kim is really fun and engaging during his lectures but my one gripe is that he moves very very slow through the whole semester. There were times that we spent over an hour on one example, which can be really helpful, but when we did the same exact example two more times in the next lectures I was fighting to stay awake

He is one of the best teacher at Stevens, I've learnt alot in this class. i will highly recommend students to take this class if you really want to learn DBMS. he's classes are very engaging and he mainly focusses on important part of subject and he is very funny.

This class is more theory heavy than 442/561. You won't be writing any sql queries and instead be learning more about the systems part of dbms which is sort of a mix of OS and algorithms. Final proj is an evaluation engine that you write for a theoretical extended version of SQL called ESQL. Tests make up half your grade but were grade leniently.

The exams (specifically midterm and final) are irrelevant to what he teaches in his class. His lecture slides are worthless you can understand a topic better by googling rather than using his lecture slides. He never teaches by running an actual SQL query in his class he is just going around theories.

Professor Kim is a genuine person and has a great sense of humor. Great class to take if you want to learn SQL. There are not many grades but the homeworks are a free 100 if you put time into it and the exams are right out of lectures.

An entire SQL class using 5 fundamentals. Impossible. Makes writing queries 10x harder than they need to be. Doesn't grade anything himself, the TAs do it. Gives no feedback or midterm and homework questions. I can't even look at my answers to the midterm. Only like 5 grades for the whole semester so if you mess one up you're screwed. Do not take
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment:
A great man once explained null values as follows:
"What is a null value? Null is nothing! I don't know!"
Also, "Dependency is best explained by filing taxes. If two claim the same dependent, the IRS will have a problem with you."
10/10 would take again.

Prof Kim was the only professor that made me hate SQL, the subject is very easy and the materials were very enough for the course. However, he was wasting lots of time talking about unimportant ideas then force all students to show up at every lecture even the extra ones that he had to schedule because he was behind. This teacher was the worst ever
rating_tags: Tough grader--So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: TAKE ONLIN DBMS INSTEAD.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Sam Kim is wonderful. He clearly knows what he is talking about and makes a genuine effort to answer everyone's questions. He explains concepts super well and makes sure we are well prepared for exams and homeworks. Very accessible outside of class. Genuinely nice guy. I wish the class had more grades (we only had 6). Too lenient with extensions.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: This class is essentially the same as 561 but its for undergrads. Really enjoyed this class and you do learn a lot of useful stuff about SQL and designing a db schema. I felt that the questions on the tests were, for the most part, very fair and straight from the slides/lectures. HWs can be pretty difficult but Kim does go over them in class.

His lectures are very simple to follow, and he is one of the funniest professors. You have a lot of time to complete the one project for his class. To do well on exams, take note of what he writes down on the board, practice MF/EMF queries, and study the practice exercises meticulously. If you go to all his lectures, you will learn a lot!

Professor's teaching style is incredible and you do really learn a lot. If you are taking this class just for a grade then I wouldn't recommend this. But if you want to learn this is one of the best classes Stevens offers.
Instead take online dbms.

Nothing that he teaches is useful in work but whatever he teaches, he teaches well. You'll learn complex queries using 5 basic aggregate functions and relational algebra. Prof. should update the course and include functions we actually use in work. Lectures are offline(so are the office hours). If you skip class you can't pass the difficult exams.
His tests are extremely hard, prepare to spend all your time working on ridiculously complex assignments.
For your own good, avoid him. He is the most unorganized professor I have encountered
He is the worst professor I have ever met.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He is funny and knowledgeable about the topic.

Take some other class if you want to learn and care about grades. An experienced data engineer said for an intro class, the hw queries are unreasonably hard, and test on 9 SQL questions in 2.5 hours cannot be done successfully by someone without prior exp. He was right, professor curves but overcomplicated material. Troule articulating concepts!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: This course does not have any homework, only two exams and one project. The project is 50% of total grade. But he won't explain it very early which means you might very busy in last few weeks. The exam is hard, he won't let you do any SQL exercise. However, you will see lots of SQL questions in exam.
His assignments and exams are hard. Doesn't grade assignments and exams properly, If grade matters for you doesn't opt his course.
Just take this class, you can't find a better one in SIT like this one!

DON'T EVEN THINK for a second CS 561 is an easy class. When comes to exam, you will feel like it's the end of the world. 9/10 query questions, those questions is similar to hw, definitely not enough time to do.. usually take me hours to think when I work on the hw, 2 hours 30 mins for the exam is not enough..
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: If you are taking the 561 then you are fine. This professor is engaging and you will start from the basic which refreshes your memory about databases. But the problem is in 562. Unnecessary allocation of EMF query which he helped in devising. The concept is not even authorized by SQL. Exms (lengthy) and project most people get it of internet. no562
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This guy only cares about the money, but he doesn't deserve that totally. This class is too redundant and makes no sense. He never gives any feedback for your assignments or grades, he puts grades very late without any visible evaluations so that you wouldn't have the chance to argue for that. A dealer rather than a professor. Should be kicked out.

He is a great teacher, but teaches very few concepts from the prescribed text. Exams/project are heavily based on a new 'such that' clause this Prof was involved in devising. So this course is only useful if you are doing a Ph.D on this clause (known as ESQL). No idea how he grades, the highest is usually A- . Wish he taught more from the textbook.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures--Tough grader

comment: It has been a nightmare for me to solve the assignments and midterm and final term exams. The amount of time provided by him to solve the exams is too less I don't think even the TA would be able to solve in such limited time. He does not conduct any labs and just teaches you all theory there are zero practicals and demonstrations of SQL.
Less homework or assignments
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: tough grader
Great Professor .Very Knowledgeable and amazingly explains the concepts. Best Professor at Stevens
Really great teaching skill and class.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Very good professor. I highly recommend all of you to take his courses.

He is the best professor in Stevens Institute of Technology. Never miss his class. Because of him, I have learned a lot about Database and I can proudly say I can answer questions about Database in any company interviews. His teaching capability is amazing and he explains each concept thoroughly. He cracks good jokes and makes a better atmosphere

PROs: # Extremely engaging lectures that are fun. # Repeats stuff multiple times and really wants students to grasp the material. # Assignments are thought provoking. # Provides a structure of the kind of question he'll ask on tests. CONs: # HWs and tests are quite hard and time taking. BE PREPARED! # Not a lenient grader and grades on a curve.

This is a great class. But... Don't expect an A or even a A-. People who score great gets an A-(a guy who scored 98 in mid term and 88 in final, 100 in both assignments got an A-) :O A guy who scored 40 in MT and 60 in Final gets a B, same grade as mine, me who gets 72 in MT and 65 in final. Fair? I don't think so!  PS. Exams are Hard! Be Prepared!

Lectures are nice and professor is hilarious but exams are too difficult and so much biased in grading towards students. Only chinese students get good grades in exams because of chinese TA. All other students do not get an A.

Prof. Kim always answers the students' questions very quickly and very willing to help you understand the difficulties encountered in the assignment. This course requires the foundation of algorithms and must be carefully prepared for exams.
lecture is great,but his assignment is tough for me,and exam is difficult
Awesome teacher with poor grading. Dont expect more than b grade.

Likes - Clarity of concepts, friendliness of prof., interesting assignments. Dislikes- Unfair Grading(I got to know that grading is biased towards non-chinese students. Friends of TAs sit together to check papers, including their's). When i cross checked my paper, i found that more marks were deducted for me than that of my chinese friend.
Make sure you study and do the practice questions. He tells you the types of questions he will ask on the exams, but they are still difficult.
Nice guy, gives clear lectures.  Tests are tough but he curves.
A knowledgeable professor. Knows his subject very well.
An excellent professor.
very good lecturer, knows subject well and fun to listen to.  Tests were rather hard, but does grade on a curve.  Assignments fairly easy and had plenty of time to do them.

Subject was a little difficult the above comment is completly wrong, he works with the students so that everyone recieves a good grade, in my class a 40% was a C and a 75 and up was an A so i doubt that recieving an 85 is a C so maybe hes talking about a different professor, his tests are hard but he is very fair in grading and working with student
The worse professor ever..got like 87 in the finals..but ended up gettin a C in the course..teaches the subject ok..but grading is really bad and the assignments are tough and useless

the professor is being  chill, the course has like 24+ assignments, and some of them need to be redone a few times, but it really helps you get better. There are also tests, projects, and exercises that keep you super busy in comparison with other subjects. If you want an A or B, be ready to redo stuff. Overall, the course pushes you to grow .

He does not teach anything. I can't emphasize this enough. He's constantly late or cancels class last minute; obviously uses Chat GPT to grade and marks correct quiz answers as incorrect. A colossal waste of money and time. He will have a class sit in silence for over 30 min each class period while he plays on his computer. Nonstop rambling. 0/10.
He was a great professor! I would definitely take another course from this professor.

He is a bit soft-spoken, but he really knows his stuff! If you read the book, do the labs and projects ( (databases and Python coding), and pay attention to his lectures, you'll do fine. He is very approachable, and if you have any questions, he is more than willing to help you. Take his class, and I promise you will learn a lot!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Decent professor for graduate Java course, cares more about you actually learning, however, tests are more based on what's taught in class, so take good notes. Lectures are more concept based so not a lot of examples, but if you listen in class you'll do fine.
one of the best proffessor
Best teacher I have ever had. HIGHLY recommend taking his class.

You're better off just teaching yourself through outside sources. He never finishes explaining the content of the class and most of the time the information he's teaching is incorrect or in a different coding language entirely. When you ask questions, he only gives circular responses and ends up being more confused than you. Nice guy, bad professor

You'll pass the class, but you won't learn a thing. He takes all his material from various sources online, and when he does refer to a textbook, didn't inform us of a second textbook till over halfway through the semester. He won't tell you his office hours, and uses the wrong coding language on quizzes. You never know what to study.
TRAUMA.

didn't learn a single thing in this class, but all the exams were based on the discussion questions so they were easy. do the work and you will pass. don't even bother showing up to the lecture; it's a waste of time. bad professor, but sweet old man.
Prof Banduk was extremely caring about his students. Although his lectures were slow and boring, he made sure everyone knew the material. Tests were very easy.

Really easy going course. Professor is very playful and easy on grading. Took this in my first semester and everyone I think got an A+. Recommend to take this course if other subjects are tough and you want a far lesser stress time saving course. Midterm and Final were easy. All in all take this course if you want an A+.
Best professor ever! Down to earth and practical!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Respected

comment: He is an excellent professor-passionate about his subject! If you are in university to learn something-TAKE HIS CLASS-HE'S GREAT!  He also has high expectations and will not lower his standards to please lazy students. He is a great professor and really helped students with many required coursework projects.
So easy. He is funny and nice, alright lectures, very free exams.
Decent professor, easy A if you just do your work and memorize the material.
The professor is amazing and chill
I have had him for two courses. He knows his stuff, and explains it very well. He is a great professor.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: He is one of the kindest professors I have ever had the honor of working with. Probably the only Stevens professor to actually help ALL of his students
great for someone new to computer science
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Overall, a good prof who helps his students understand the computer programming in order to excel you need to put in the time and effort.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Amazing professor. He gets right to the point and tells you what you need to know for the test. He is very interesting as well as knowledgeable. Professor is willing to help as long as you put forth the effort. I highly recommend him. He's a great professor and he genuinely cares.
The professor is a very eye-opening, kind individual! I CS 105 served as a brilliant introduction to computer programming. Overall though, he is a fascinating prof. and the class was a delight!
For anyone who wants to take this professor for his class, I'd recommend. His class is really exciting and engaging. Truly the professor I enjoyed learning from at Stevens! Many interesting projects!

Prof Banduk was an excellent teacher when I had him for 105! Clear, concise, and gets the computer programming subject across in a very easy manner to learn from. I am glad that he extended the due dates for my two past due programs(we completed 8 programs). Don't miss the submission of labs, each graded lab has points for your final course grade
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: He knows his course material, and explains it very well. He is a great professor.

The professor really wants to help her students learn Python programming. He really helped me with my coding labs and the hands-on skills needed to become a developer. He is very lenient and takes labs late. Coding is exciting! Amazing lecturer, inspirational and caring!

He's very sincere, and genuine. He is also very reasonable with grading and is fairly clear on his expectations. It was very interesting to learn key programming concepts like variables and functions by using popular Python language ( like a real programmer). Professor will guide you through each step. Youll learn the right coding!

He was hard to understand and didnt like it when people asked questions during class. If you need help with coding, he would just say to do it again without offering any type of feedback. He would also get mad when you submitted a lab early (as in the night before it was due), but would tell you half a week in advance that you were missing a lab.

Professor Banduk is an amazing professor and genuinely cares about his students. He is very kind, personable, and easily the most approachable professor on campus. Overall a great class, you will not regret it!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Very well organized and always ready to teach. Super nice professor.
Have an outstanding ability to cover and convey the material clearly. An amazing professor who really cares about his students.
The course was well taught and organized and the professor was always very responsive, which I find helpful.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria

comment: 4 projects, 2 exams, multiple homework Does a great job teaching a hard course!

By far one of the best professors I've ever had! He is an engaging lecturer, an effective professor, and incredibly kind and understanding, expectations are straightforward, and you'll learn so much. Absolutely take a class with him!
Extremely confusing, never know what is going on in class.
Tons of extra credit. CS 105 with Professor Banduk is one of the easiest classes you'll ever take. However, if you actually want to learn computer science, I'd avoid this class.

Professor Banduk is very attentive! He encourages and responds well to your participation. There is a very fair amount of work given in this class, none of which is too challenging, but all of which can be very beneficial, if you actually put in the effort to learn it. Also, this course is a good CS prereq.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Solid class, great professor!
TAKE HIM!!! A true saint of Stevens. Please teach CPE 517 and help me complete my Computer Architecture minor. :)

CPE550 is cross-listed with CS550. Banduk is the definition of the best professor here at Stevens. In person or online he's great for both. Really hope he teaches other classes in the future. The CPE/CS department needs more professors like him.

The total course points can be deducted for each missing or incomplete assignment . But, I like that professor is always clear on his marking criteria. He is allowing to submit homework after the due date. New assignment (including programming codes) every week. Actually, CS 550 is the best class I took this semester!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: My difficult part was couple assignments which are required calculations (I forgot my math from undergrad. Prof. provided and explained multiple examples for each chapter. Review these examples before quizzes
good professor!

He is a nice and responsive professor. This was an online course so things were laid out with a standard format. You have weekly homeworks then quizzes and exams. The questions are multiple choice. The information is very basic and you just need to read and study for the exams. There is a time limit for exams and quizzes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: The Professor almost just read from slides. However, he is very kind, and helpful.  Gives clear outlines for the exams. Easy assignments. The textbook is very good. In short, an easy A
Good teacher.
Unfortunately Prof. Borowski is leaving Stevens in the 2021F semester. Very sad to see but I wish him the greatest in his industry work! Truly the best CS professor Stevens had in my time attending.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Assignments are challenging and Dr. Borowski is incredibly strict. But I can't deny that he is great at teaching and wants to make sure students learn as much as possible

Professor Borowski cares about his students and wants them to succeed. His lectures are clear and informative, and his assignments are tough, but fair, especially with the inclusion of a test script and his accessibility and willingness help (just dont start last minute!) Very positive experience in his class overall.

Be ready to suffer in his classes and have sleepless nights of endless self doubts and negative thoughts. He tends to show you that he is the nicest and kindest teacher you would ever meet. On the flip side, he is there to horrify you with his AP Style tests that don't teach anything just to make you feel stupid.

Dr. B is an excellent professor. He is good at communicating his very strong understanding of the subject, and he cares that his students succeed both in class and in their careers. He consistently puts aside a large portion of his time to help students and make sure that they understand the material and have the tools they need to succeed.
One of the best professors at Stevens

CS 385 - Borowski is an awesome professor. If you really want to learn the ins and outs of computer science, Borowski is the way to go. He will always be open to help any student. He keep the class fun and interesting. The online semester has been tough for him though as it is harder to convey material online, but he tried his best to do so.

Dr.B is a great professor, his teaching style is easy to follow. However, he tends to focus more on grades and acts like a robot, without giving a chance to students to focus on learning but rather to worry all the time about their grades. All his quizzes /codes run through a script, so is ready to lose a lot of points for the slightest mistake.
Easily the best professor at Stevens, you are actually able to learn so much from lectures and participating in class definitely helps you understand the concepts better!
Great professor, one of the most respected CS professors in the department. You will learn a lot from him and he cares about his students.

Dr. B has been easily the best professor I've studied under at Stevens. He genuinely cares about his students' learning and it shows. His lectures are easy to follow and he actively tries to keep the class interested and involved. Friendly, accessible in and outside of class, Dr. Borowski is an exceptional and passionate professor. Don't Cheat.

Borowski is a legend. Engaging lectures. Did I do terrible in his class? Yeah but that's because I realized CS wasn't for me. So in a sense, this class led me to better things. Class is based on HW, labs, and tests. The tests are written, but if you make a tiny mistake, you will get little to no credit for the question. Definitely check your work!!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Honestly one of the best CS professors at stevens. His tests aren't always the easiest, but he is really knowledgeable about the material and communicates it effectively. He makes an effort to know most students on a personal level. He really wants to help you succeed, as long as you're willing to put in the effort.

Incredible Professor, Dr. B truly cares about what he does and really wants each of his students to succeed. Keeps lectures interesting and informative, constantly tying what you do into tangible real-life examples. If I could have him for every class, I would do it.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This guy is the man
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. B is a damn good professor. He taught the course well and he cares about the students and wants them to succeed. Don't really have anything to add on to all these other reviews here, he's great.

Really not much to say here that hasn't already been said. Dr. B is as about as good as it gets. He's caring, accessible, funny, and an effective teacher. When my class did horribly on the first test, he took time to give study tips and listen to us explain why the test was hard. He does teach quite fast, so don't be afraid to ask questions.

Borowski is an amazing professor and i wish i could have him for all of my cs classes. He is very passionate about cs and teaching and it shows. He does a great job at explaining concepts and is very communicative. You will be challenged but learn so much in all of his classes. He is also funny and his lectures are enjoyable every time
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Borowski is a great professor who genuinely cares about each of his students. Even while having 70 students, he manages to know most people on an individual level. Ask questions in class, he always tries to make sure everyone is understanding the material. This was a great class, I really began loving programming after taking this course.
If I could take every single one of my classes with Dr. B I would.

Borowski, always the man of the hour in CS 115. He has made my freshman year at Stevens a blast! His class is always fair and even though there can be tough twists and turns here and there, he makes himself available in every way. He always asks the class for ways that he can help his students.

Literally the best professor ever. Truly cares about the success of his students, and knows everyone by name. Amazing lectures with a hint of his not-so-funny jokes. Extra credit is there, but he makes you work for it. His grading is strict but definitely fair. Homework is challenging but he's super helpful and sometimes gives big hints in class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. B is one of the best computer science professors I have ever had the pleasure of learning from. I learned more in his one semester intro class than I did in two years of high school comp sci courses. He really wants all of the students to succeed.
Amazing professor. He will give answers to programming assignments in class. Go to class or else you won't pass. Really wants his students to succeed. Fair grader and great teacher.

Really wants his students to succeed and encourages students to ask questions, you'll have to show up to class if you want to do well, especially to follow along with his code demonstrating the concepts he's teaching (some functions we wrote in class showed up exactly the same on the test). He's a funny guy and gives out extra credit occasionally.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Great guy and a thoughtful professor who genuinely cares about whether or not you're learning.

Borowski is awesome. He makes CS 115 interesting and time flies when we are in class. Homework is tough and the course moves fast, but tests aren't really hard. He cares about students and is available outside class to help when needed.
Super fair, super dedicated to helping his students. One of the hardest working professors at Stevens. Wish he taught more advanced classes.

TAKE ALL OF HIS CLASSES. Borowski is by far the best professor I have ever had. He is the only professor that cares so much for his students. He wants to see his students succeed and makes you work to earn as much experience as you can get. His classes aren't just classes but fun experiences.

Best Computer Science professor in the department, actually cares about his students and gives great advice, very accessible and willing to give help, challenges students and gives fantastic lectures. Makes it funny. 10/10 would reccomend

Professor Borowski is awesome. He really cares about the students, conveys the material clearly and is always willing to go back and explain if needed. His jokes are terrible but funny in a geeky way. I wish he taught courses beyond CS385. I learned a ton with him and would definitely have him as a professor again.
You can tell he enjoys teaching. Makes lectures interesting for students who don't like CS. There's a homework assignment and lab due each week, but there are plenty of options for getting help.
Really friendly guy. Knows all his students by name. Can be a tough grader but his exams/hw are usually fair.
One of the best professors at Stevens. Knows his stuff and really wants his students to succeed. Terrible puns, though. Just laugh anyway.
Awesome professor. Explains material well. Prepare for hard homework and isn' t too lenient on grading.
He's a great professor, he likes getting the class engaged during lectures, and he really knows what he's talking about.
fun time. hard assignments

Borowski rocks. His first time teaching this course, but he adapts to assignments and what students need well. If he assigns something that people aren't getting, he eases up on the grading or will actually explain it instead of just leaving you to flounder.   Awesome professor, awesome class, jokes are terrible but laugh anyway for extra credit
A great teacher who really wants his students to succeed.

Dr. B is one of the most dedicated and fair professors that I have met on campus.  It is evident that all of his lectures are well planned, not only supplying you with material you need to know, but also leaving you with the ability to apply it.  If you're ever unsure, Dr. B is able to help you with anything you did not understand. Just ask!
Awesome teacher. Explains material very well. Tests are not tough if you understand the material. Ask for help and he'll help you. Dr. B is the boy.

Maz is the forking man. 

"First we cry, the we do calculus"
Educator of the very highest standard. Lectures crystal clear. Material stays with you forever

Maz is a great professor. His lecture examples are really helpful in understanding how to solve the problems. The homework problems are very hard, but they're worth 4 points each. The test problems are much easier, but he does not give partial credit. You have to be pretty perfect on his tests to do well. Note: the final is  usually  4 hours long

Maz is a great guy and professor. He expects your all for the class. The homeworks are tough but for the tests, they are much easier the questions. I would focus on the tests more. He has old exams on his website. Very smart guy all around. I would definitely take him again.
He's the worst. I have a hard time believing he wants students to succeed.

One of the best math classes I ever took.  Mazmanian is a gifted lecturer.  His notes are so clear and concise, I hardly had to refer to textbook.  Tests can be hard, but if you study the notes carefully, you'll be on safe ground.  He got me so interested that I started to do a math masters in addition to my coursework.
His tests are difficult but he's a very funny and understanding guy. See him after the tests and he'll help get some points.

Maz is fantastic.  He really knows his stuff and is a great teacher.  Most impressive thing though is that he uses no notes in class, just straight from his head to the board.  Sense of humor makes class easier to deal with.
Incredible teacher, inside and outside class
Looks can be deceiving till you have the ultimate maz experience. I hope  the lord continues to strengthen Him so he can continue to deliver.
Funny accent. Tests are hard but fair.

he's so cute! and at first verryyyy intimidating but once the "ice breaks" hes a very caring and helpful teacher and i LOVE his subtle sence of sarcastic humor. It's the best. you will definitely learn in his class!
If TF2's Heavy was a math professor, he'd be Maz.

Not as great as his reputation. Instead of explaining the tricks of calculus he just does example after example without actually explaining anything. This works well for the majority of engineering students who just want to "plug and chug", but to those who need a conceptual understanding of the material, it makes MA221 impossible.

Hardest class I've taken so far at Stevens, but by far the most rewarding. He is a difficult teacher, but if you work hard and pay attention, you will learn a lot. He has a very subtle, but funny, sense of humor.

Yes, he's gonna give out easy tests so you can effortlessly get an A+, but if you do your hw and go to class there is no reason why you can't do well. He is helpful if you go to him during office hours and ask for extra help. Plus doing problems is really the only way to learn this calc crap, not pointless proofs and theory.
Gives the worlds hardest tests, but you WILL learn. He is the MAN
Very helpful guy. Acts tough, but really wants everyone to learn, succeed and think for themselves.
No one's college is complete without having had the 'Maz Experience'. He's hard, but he's an awesome professor.
Genuinely cares about his students, both in and out of the class room.  One of Steven's best!
I love maz. He is an awesome teacher. Everyone thinks he is hard, but if you study and pay attention, it is actually not that bad.

I graduated 9 years ago and after receiving 2 grad degrees am convinced he is the worst professor I have ever had.  Worse than the professors who cannot speak English or drone on.  His smugness is unbareable.  His exams highlight his passive/agressive personality.  I received an A in his class by attending other prof's classes starting 3rd week

In this class, the material is very difficult to understand and Maz just writes a bunch of problems on the board. He has a massive curve because his tests are so difficult (when they shouldn't be). He's tests were very hard and not like the homework at all.I would take Maz for Ma221 but not take him for Ma227.
No Comments

I had him in Ma221 and I didn't think he was bad. I walked out of that class with an A...this year, in Ma227, he made the tests even harder and its almost impossible to study for them. I'm going to be Lucky to get a B. If you want a high GPA, avoid him.
No Comments
No Comments

He is a really good math teacher. He has a lot of teaching experience, and he actually teaches the information that's pertinent. While I do believe that the theoretical aspects of mathematics are very important, Maz teaches us the information that is essential to an engineer. He also prepares you for his very hard tests, but it involves a lot of listening and attention. Overall, I recommend him strongly.

Best Math teacher I have ever had at Stevens.  Gives clear examples and if you do your homework and the review sheets he gives you, you'll do fine on his exams.  This is NOT a class you can BS through, but you will definitely learn if you do the work that is expected of you.

Did my homework, took his notes, when it came time for the final I didn't even need to study... and I got an A!  He can be hard, but you learn everything you need to know from him... and you learn it instead of just getting to last minute cram.
Maz is the man!  Sure his tests are hard, but if you take notes and do your homework, they are a breeze!

He is definately the best teacher I've had at Stevens so far. Although he is tough, you learn everything you need to learn. Only a couple of teachers have affected me before and he definately has to be one of them.
Maz is the worst, any professor that memorizes your face to your social security # should be fired.  This is also a case of too many examples, not enough theory clearly explained.....
Great professor...tough, but you walk out of his class knowing your stuff.

Attendance is mandatory. He explains material better than the book; in fact there is no need to read the book other than to do the assigned problems. He has a massive curve so if you get an 80 on tests, your set for an A. He's one of Stevens' best profs.

Maz is by far the best math teacher I've ever had. I didn't do great in his class but I sure did learn. With him, I can actually conceptualize the math and understand it. All other math prof pale in comparison.

Maz is one of the good professors at Stevens if you are willing to learn. He is very structured in teaching Calculus and you have to understand what he is getting at. Spends more time on problems than theory.
No Comments
No Comments
worst teacher ive ever had here at stevens. HANDS DOWN!
No Comments
No Comments

this class let alone professor is absolutely abysmal. not only do i not understand the content i also have to try to decipher what he is saying through his Russian mafia boss accent. i also have received a few emails and comments from him I would expect to hear from a drunk single father at a strip club bar.

Honestly your better off teaching yourself the material. He jumps around way to much during class to the point where if you zone out for a couple of seconds your going to be lost for the rest of the class. Also he has a super thick accent which makes it even harder to understand him.
Absolutely no idea what this guy says, let alone listening him lecture hear eqn and laplace transform.

Honestly I didn't pay much attention during his lectures. Given his thick accent, if you zone out during class it's pretty easy to get lost. However, when I did pay attention (usually after tests when I was finally caught up with the material) I found his lectures helpful. He's great with answering questions, especially while reviewing for tests.

Ok so I may have a bias because I love Calc but he's an excellent professor and offers plenty of extra credit chances. There are weekly assignments that each offer bonus points. He also began mandatory attendance since so few people were showing up. Hands down the best prof for Diff Eq by far. If you can get past the accent you'll be just fine.
Best Mathematics professor at Stevens. Very intelligent, great personality, and lessons were not boring. Enjoyed the class and 100% would take it again. Helped after class if needed.

What the other review about MA 635 said: professor is very sharp and knows the course, but sometimes is disorganized in its presentation. The latter half of the course is easier than the first conceptually. The textbook is on the easier side and so it functions well to supplement lecture without difficulty. Generous grader. Exams are entire grade.
Very Unorganized!! Knows his things well, but cant teach!!

His accent is hard to understand but besides that he's a great and funny teacher. The lectures move very fast but only because he has so little time to teach all the material. When given a chance to take it slow, he's great at explaining. Homeworks are difficult and you will need to spend time studying before/after class, but it's well worth it.

Dr. Dubovskiy is a great professor. He's hilarious, thorough, and passionate about math. The real question is whether or not you'll understand any of his jokes through that accent. He doesn't give as much feedback on his grading quizzes as I would like. MA124 is definitely a class you'll have to work in, but he himself is willing to help you.

Besides the accent issue, he's a good prof. He teaches the concepts never worse than decently and often very well. The textbook is not necessary but a reasonable supplement for the topics he gives a semi-long proof but not many numerical examples for. Something about his smile and laugh when a 3D function has no critical points: it's priceless.

Great professor. If you study ahead of time (like you really should in college), you'll do fine. If you put off homework until the last second and then start cramming, you'll be lucky to pass. Although he doesn't go by the textbook, following along in the textbook is highly encouraged. Make sure you do the practice problems from the book!!
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Your typical Russian professor - he knows what he's doing, but sometimes struggles to effectively teach some of the topics and sometimes his work on the board makes no sense. You won't need textbooks for lecture, but you will for recitation. If you can pay attention and not get distracted, you should be able to learn the material well.

Heavy accent. Prepares nothing. Does everything off the top of his head. Loosely follows the course syllabus. Comes into class exactly on time or a couple minutes late. Weird sense of humor and laugh you will grow to love (or hate). Classwork rarely reflects homework. I would skip lectures but attendance is taken like 4 times throughout the course.

Unable to understand him. I would say you should go to class because every once in a while you get important equations necessary to do well in the class. however most of the time he spends the entire class teaching the unnecessary theoretical ideas of topics. find a tutor for this class and pay attention to recitation otherwise will fail.

I only had him for a 1-credit pass/fail class, and passed.  By the skin of my teeth.  The class was far more difficult than its credit weight and pass/fail status would imply; it was about abstract concepts in discrete math, and he knew his stuff, but was not very good at communicating it.

Some people don't mind Dubovskiy's teaching style, but I wasn't a fan of it. He came to almost every lecture unprepared and when he taught, he improvised and flew by the seat of his pants. Although he's helpful when you ask questions, he was rarely in his office, didn't respond to any emails, and was all around, a very irresponsible professor.

I love this dude! He is so passionate about math that it almost makes me want to be a math major. The accent is not a problem if you really focus in class. You're 100% prepared for tests and he is so helpful with questions. I really hope to have him for differential equations next semester!!
Very helpful when I asked questions. He is also very clear about what will be on the tests.

Dubs gets a lot of flak because he has such a thick accent. But that shouldn't stop you from doing well in his class - he definitely knows his stuff; he'll answer any questions clearly. He's an excellent professor, and really a nice guy. Don't be afraid to ask him questions.
Great teacher except for his damn russian accent

Obviously a very smart man, but he showed up to lectures late more often than not and was unprepared for them the vast majority of the time. Taking this class over the summer with him was probably a bad idea, considering the pacing and that he was hardly ever available outside of class.

Quite brilliant, but doesn't seem to prepare lecture beforehand (leads to some moments where he's staring at the board coming up with an example problem). Homework is sometimes off-topic. Tests are very fair, and over-prepares students during lecture. Overall enjoyed his class; also, if he offers stickers, they might become extra credit.

He is a really smart professor. His lectures tend to get boring, since they get really theoretical, but he solves difficult problems in class to make sure students are well prepared for the tests. It's quite difficult to understand him sometimes.

many of the previous reviews were in large lecture halls, i've taken him for quite a few classes, including a small seminar with less than 20 students.  he does have a thick russian accent, but good luck finding a prof in the math department who doesn't. his tests are pleasantly challenging. he's a fun guy who has a passion for what he does.

Nice guy, but I hated him. I never understood what he was trying to explain. Sometimes would spend whole lecture on problem then say it was wrong, and it had nothing to do with homework or test. Too much theory and not enough examples. Only C I ever received at Stevens

I. Love. This. Man.  He is so good at teaching and even though his tests are difficult it is so worth it.  You really do get a lot out of his class.  He is also very understanding with extensions of homework if the lectures fall behind.  Definitely my favorite teacher of all time.

He is such a nice guy but I couldn't understand much of what he was saying in class. It's not his fault, but you do have to try extra hard to get the lectures. Although you may hear some of his Russian phrases which are quite humorous. This class is hard and unless you pay attention, go to recitations, and keep up with homework, you will be lost.
No one can understand his accents. He makes things more complicated than they really are. If you HAVE to take him like I did, just learn on your own, you'll be better off.
<3 <3 <3

Pavel is a very good teacher. Thick accent but if you can get past that (which isn't that difficult) you will learn a lot. One of the nicest guys I've ever met, in all honesty. One of the smartest too.

He deffiantly knows his stuff, but I never have any idea what he's talking about when it comes to the more difficult topics. Very nice, but im doing terrible and I was really good at math before his class.
Very knowledgeable and always willing to help. However, he is very hard to understand with his very thick Russian accent. Make sure to actually do the homeworks to keep up.
Amazing! Must be the funniest guy I've ever taken a class from! I'm taking another class from him, for sure.
Will not quit until you get it! He teaches harder examples in class so that the exam seems easier. Great Professor!
Thick accent, but really knows his stuff. He make everything crystal clear
Pavel Dubovskiy: Great teacher... or greatest teacher?

Very nice guy.  Accent is a bit thick, but you can deal.  Eventually, the accent will lend itself to jokes, and you'll have a good time with it.  Funny guy at times, and very friendly.  Willing to help if you ask for it, and gives Ex Cred if you participate in class.  If you understand the work, do it well, and act interested, you'll do well.

Very good professor if you pay attention!  Sure his accent is a little difficult sometimes, but you do get used to it.  He's obviously very smart and really wants his students to do well.  If you don't understand something, he's very approachable and he wants to make sure you get it!  Also yes very well dressed haha

It took me the entire semester to figure out what the heck he was saying. I can't understand anything he says. It's a ridiculuously tough course. If you want to do well, take a bunch of practice exams online and get a tutor!

hahhhaha love Pavel......I dont care how bad he teaches but everyday I looked forward to going to class and hearing him say "kaa-sine" (cosine).....love the russian accent.....and also hes a good dresser...have you seen his snake skin leather shoes?/?
bah... pain and torture, and then, some more pain
No Comments
Teaches, does not read off slides. Does helpful examples and can answer questions.

Billah is the best professor at the university hands down. Passionate and a true expert at his craft, he is dedicated to academia and teaching students the material. Had him for both Mechanics of Solids and Structural Analysis, and he's helped me to build some of the best foundations in those subjects within the department.

Billah has said he doesn't care about ratings but he's a real gem! Based opinions on education and learning. Participate as it's the one thing keeping him sane with how bad the course is structured. He may call on people to teach what u learned. He can be daunting at first but he lightens up. You should strive to have him. put a kirkle in my heart!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational

comment: Unfortunately, Prof. Billah did not have control of the course curriculum this semester. Regardless, he taught us as best he could, and he did a damn good job. He is a super sensible and very passionate man that loves teaching. He will fight to make sure you understand a topic. He is a Steven's gem, and you should try your best to take him!

Amazing professor who really cares about his students. His priority is to make sure that students understand the material and can apply concepts to problems on their own. It is clear he really cares about his students' success in the future and goes out of his way to help students. He also likes to joke around at times, which is pretty enjoyable.

Love Professor Billah. He actually cares whether or not you understand the material. Will give you an extension if you need it. He loves when you answer questions in class, especially if you're wrong!

Every professor should strive to match the excellence displayed in Professor Billah's teaching skills. He makes complex concepts very easy to understand, and he has fun with it as well. He does everything in his power to help the students, and will always do his best to meet with students out of class to clear up any confusion. Please Check.

Billah is by far the best professor I have had here. He makes complex topics seem very manageable and he doesn't rest until everyone understands. I used to go to his office hours just for help, but now he's my faculty advisor and I go just to talk to him. Truly a gem at stevens.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Prof. Billah was great. He breaks down every problem so that anyone in the class can understand it. I would take his class again any time. If you have the opportunity to take his class for E 126, make sure that you have him.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: He's the only one teaching Mech Solids so there's no point of looking here. But he's a great instructor. Teaching wise 10/10. Difficulty of exams also 10/10.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY--Tests are tough

comment: Great Instructor but very difficult exam. Dont walk into Billah's class thinking it will be an easy A because you are mistaken. Especially don't be fooled by the curve. You have to study a lot and put additional time outside the lecture.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--TEST HEAVY

comment: Greatest professor Ive ever had. Stresses the importance of thinking and his classes will help you in every other class.

Billah is honestly one of the most respected teachers I've ever had at Stevens. He seems intimidating at first (even had a bad first encounter with him), but I never missed a single lecture (and I tend to miss others like E&M lol). But if you go to class, take good notes, and practice, you'll be in good shape. He's great for help one on one too!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Great professor. Makes a dry subject very interesting and engaging. Ensures a full comprehension of everything from advanced engineering principals to the very basics of calculus.   Everything you would want in a professor, assuming you are looking to learn.

Billah is actually wants to teach and he is good at it. Going to lectures and doing homework will guarantee a good grade. People say that for most classes, but for Billah you do not have to teach yourself anything since he explains things very well. Also intimidating at first but he is funny. My grade was because I did not do the homework.
Wants his students to learn and succeed, makes boring subjects interesting, strict when he needs to be but not too much. Great at explaining concepts, fantastic instructor.
Finally a professor that stresses learning rather than grades Pay attention in lecture and you'll do fine
He is great.
If you go to his office hours he will definitely help. He may look strict but he honestly cares for his class
I have a lot of respect for this Professor. One of those rare professors that successfully translate his knowledge into teachings for his students.

Billah is the probably the most helpful teacher I have ever taken at Stevens, and I'm not even a civil engineer! Lectures are concise and follow a logical order. Actually teaches to the class using chalkboard examples rather than a Powerpoint. Attended every lecture. If you are smart and hardworking you will excel in his classes.

Perhaps the best teacher I have had so far at Stevens. Very enthusiastic about the material he teaches, and definitely tries his hardest to make the material relevant to his students. Excellent at teaching the strategies and thinking behind the problems that we do in class, and emphasizes that we analyze each problem rather than memorizing.

The best mech of solids professor you could get. Only one to really hammer in your head how to solve problems by teaching you the strategy and thinking behind solving various problems. Also amusing that he gave out cookies/oreos in class randomly for morning classes under the reason for "brain food." Anyways very clear in teaching and also helpful.
Great teacher. Very helpful and always available to provide help. His class isnt easy but it is enjoyable.
really good teacher, if you pay attention you will learn from him. i actually look forward to his class.

Had him for Mech Solids and Structures. Billah is a very good teacher - he teaches well, engages students, and although his tests are hard, the grading is very lenient. Finals are long though. He's very easy to talk to, but is a little harebrained. Is pretty friendly in his office, but don't get on his bad side.
Had for multiple courses and he was a terrific teacher. Even assisted me with clarification for a course he wasn't teaching.

He's one of the best prof you can find here. He teaches with clarity and always wanted you to participate in his class. He promotes thinking and make sure that you understand the lessons. You'll love this guy
Great clarity & reasonable grading. Very interesting lectures.
Knows what he's talking about. Doesnt like when people memorize. Tests are hard but he curves. GOod if he knows you
He is a wonderful teacher. I could have not understood without him teaching. Great advisor too! Everybody loves Prof Billah
I had Professor Billah for Structures.  He was a great teacher. and the class was pretty interesting.  The class was pretty interesting, and I retained a lot of the material.
Best professor at Stevens
one of my favorite professors thus far
Awesome teacher, hated the material, and he got me through it.
No Comments
No Comments

Excellent teacher.  Really knows his stuff and makes the classes interesting if you are interested in the material.  Presents everything in a very organized way and has fair tests.  He is always asking for questions and you can tell that he enjoyes teaching.
Knows his stuff and communicates the material very well.
No Comments

Professor Fisch takes a genuine interest in all of his student's projects and gives top notch feedback. It's apparent that he really cares for his student's academic and personal growth as engineers and entrepreneurs. Additionally, the content of the course and way that he communicates it speak to the depth of his real world experience.

Professor is very kind to everyone. And everytime when we do a group project, professor will very patiently to talk to every group about the feedback. And professor is very passionate to teach us on the class.

Professor Fisch took a real interest in our team's (and the class's) success. When coming into the course the expectations were pretty low and by year's end we really appreciated the real world lessons / applications as they related to our engineering project.
He goes above and beyond to make sure you succeed beyond the scope of his class

Gene really cares about his students. This class isn't very structured- but that's because he intends for it to be more discussion-based. He wants his students to be well rounded Engineers and encourages them to be open minded about their future. He's there for anything you could need him for!

Professor Gene Fisch, Jr. is everything you hope for when paying $67,000 a year for school. He just wrote our team a letter reviewing our final project and even though I may not love everything that he said, he is the first professor to take the time to go into this level of detail. He was also always available to meet with us.
Gene Fisch, Jr (The M.I.T. guy) was awesome... Our entire team loved him (and this is before we learned our grade :) ) Serously... the definition of "great professor" is this guy.
Gene Fisch, Jr is a GREAT prof. We'd like to adopt him like a puppy (a brilliant puppy). He is the type of professor that makes you enjoy school.
Gene Fisch Jr was tremendous and by far the best professor that I've had at Stevens. Why I had to wait until year five to have him is ridiculous.
Gene Fisch Jr is a fantastic example to learn from. His knowledge base is tremendous and Stevens should give him tenure.
Gene Fisch Jr has our entire team excited about the project - pretty big switch from where we were when it was assigned to us by another professor. How did we go 5 years without taking this person?!

Gene Fisch, Jr. has exceeded my expectations that I had from reading the reviews before taking the course. The man is great. We're working on a biodiesel purification project and you would think that he wrote the book on the material. Genius...
Professor Fisch (Gene Fisch Jr - the younger professor) was great! Our class heard horror stories of the other course professors and Gene made the material understandable and fun. We were lucky.
Our professor Gene Fisch (Jr) was out of this world awesome... We totally love him.

Gene Fisch Jr did a fantastic job relaying the material of this course. Our class would hear horror stories from students with other professors and Gene was the exact opposite of what they were experiencing. He was amazing.
Gene Fisch Jr has been my favorite professor so far at Stevens.

Gene Fisch Jr did a wonderful job teaching us the material and I fully agree with the other reviews here. Our team didn't expect to enjoy the class as much as we did; in fact, it turned into our favorite class.

Absolutely fantastic... Learned about this rating system and he's the only person that I'm taking time to review. Gene Fisch, Jr. is one of those professors that you hope to get when attending a great school. First class all the way and a real stand up guy who cares about his students.
Probably the best professor that I have had in 5 years. He really gets it and understands multiple aspects of the project. Each class was interesting.
