He marches to his own drum which is something to get used to - when you do, he's the best professor you will ever have
He is one of the few professors that took a genuine interest in us. Phenomenal.
Beyond anything I could have hoped for. One of the best at Stevens

Getting ready for my final class with Professor Fisch. Gene Fisch Jr is amazing. The challenging concepts that he brought to life have changed the way that I think. He is the professor that I will remember.

Professor Fisch (Gene Fisch Jr) is a great professor. He's a character that cared about us as people rather than just a random student. He dives into our projects and the way to best solve the problems we encounter as engineers. I would take him again for any of his courses if I could.
Just finished our last class and came to review. Gene (Gene Fisch, Jr.) is terrific. Even his goodbye to us made me think about life and the big picture.
Professor Fisch (Gene Fisch, Jr.) is a great professor that really cared about us. I've read the reviews below and they are all spot on. Would love to have this person for my entire Stevens career.
Professor Gene Fisch, Jr. rocks.... We love him.

Gene Fisch Jr was great in a course that we were not excited about going in. He knows his stuff and is always ready to help out. One of the things that I personally enjoyed was the desire to teach us "life lessons" as they related to the material. It's great having a professor who has done things and then brings them into the classroom.

Gene Fisch, Jr. is one of the best Professors at Stevens. He pushed us in the first semester and we are reaping the rewards of less work in the second semester... He knows his stuff and is always there to help with whatever we need.

Without a doubt - the best professor for this subject matter.... The course is not on anyone's wish list, however, Professor Fisch (Gene Fisch, Jr.) brings it to life and was very helpful in getting our projects off the ground. Excellent job.

Gene Fisch, Jr. is awesome; my entire team loved his style. He's all about baked goods so if you want an "A".... Kidding aside, the lessons he taught extend beyond the classroom. Definitely try to take him.

Gene Fisch, Jr is fantastic! This is by far my favorite class and the environment is very positive. He jumps into every project and we always leave having learned something. I wish that all of my professors taught in the same manner as Professor Fisch.
Professor Fisch (Gene Fisch Jr) exemplifies what it is to be an amazing professor. Best choice I made this semester was taking his class.
Gene Fisch Jr really helped make our coursework come alive - one of the best prof's I had in my four years here.
Professor Fisch is fantastic and it is because of him that we look forward to coming to class. He is charismatic while also being incredibly smart in the way that he conveys the material.
Taking professor Fisch now - our entire class LOVES him. He is teaching us how to love making our ideas real. It's everything that I hoped college would be. He is brilliant.
My favorite professor during my four years here... The course itself was "meh", but Professor Fisch brought it to life. I think that I would have been miserable with a different professor.

This guy is fantastic. He teaches as if he's your friend and will go to the ends of the Earth to help your project. We had an issue with our sponsor (the Navy). He calls his contact and somehow our problem disappeared in a day. Amazing....

Gene is great. Our section seemed to have a greater work load than the others but in retrospect it was some of the most valuable work that we had during our time in college. He was always there when we needed guidance - even more so than the person who was our intended Senior Design professor. Seriously, this person is terrific

Great professor. He really cared about what we were doing. He didn't just go through the motions. There was a bunch of work in that he made us write a business plan for the device we created but in retrospect it was probably one of the more valuable parts of my education in that he showed us how to make the projects "real".
not good! will not teach anything. he thinks everyone are coders!!
dont have a syllabus he just teaches as wished and grades like som high end coders

This course is the MOST AWFUL course that I have taken. He can only teach you many useless and odd skills such as drawing some useless shapes. He put many many assignments but that only makes up 5% of grades. However, the exam is MUCH HARDER than what he lectures in the class! Do NOT take his lessons! Save your time!Save yourself!

he doesnt teach what he is supposed to teach. He spends half the class talking about his life and the other half is spent teaching us topics that are not on the curriculum. He is extremely disorganized. I hope he is fired and never teaches anyone or anything. He should not be a teacher


He should not be a teacher. 
He should not be a teacher.

This dude made our class a coding class instead of learning about actual hardware. He made the final exam extremely hard (which I failed miserably) and even the TA said that the professor intentionally made the final hard at the last second, in fact he changed so much of the exam without consulting the TA that half the test had major errors.

The organization of the lecture was haphazard at best.He jumped from one topic to another without providing.This lack of structure made it challenging to follow the intended flow of the lecture, resulting in confusion and frustration among the students.I would strongly advise others to explore alternative options.

Do you like lab assignments that are related to lecture material? Do you enjoy homework assignments with clear directions? Do you expect to be able to get help from your professor? If your answer to any of these was yes, then avoid Dov Kruger at all costs. He is singlehandedly responsible for making me second-guess my choice of major at Stevens.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: I've had many unprepared or lazy professors, but never one that doesn't even pretend to know what's going on. 80% of the course grade is exams, but during the semester we had one actual exam, and another group project that counted as our second exam grade, except the project was to basically google all the information he never really taught.

I finna be real with yall if u fail this class CPE ain't for you, this class is light as long as you have half a brain the kids complaining on this thread to put it simply CPE was not for them. You can learn almost all the material right before the test and still get a 100. Dov doesn't spoon-feed on slides, it's a breath of fresh air for stevens
worst professor at stevens and rude

Personally, I do not like the way he teaches. It's difficult to understand and follow his lectures because he gives little to no explanation why things are the way they are. The only students who seem to participate in his courses have an above-average foundation in coding and computers. No slides to follow. Canvas is practically useless his class

The syllabus for this course has dates in it from 2019 and is essentially meaningless anyway, as Prof. Kruger changes his policies suddenly and without announcement. It is easy to reach him outside of class, but that doesn't mean you'll get any meaningful help from him. He either doesn't know what's going on in his own course, or doesn't care.
rating_tags: Group projects--Graded by few things--Online Savvy

comment: This guy sucks

He's a good professor who gives out the code for us to follow.  I kind of wish there were slides for the class, but he only had a couple of days to prepare, so I don't mind.  My only negative is that he goes on long coding intervals which make less sense than usual.

I don't understand why people complain about Kruger, he is by far the most respectable, caring, communicative, and knowledgeable professor I've had at Stevens so far. He really takes time to get to know you and your needs if you just reach out to him and are willing to put in the work. Great lecture style, dynamic and engaging. he has my heart

PREFACE: My class only had him for later half of the semester and we did x86 not ARM. Dov is very obviously smart and knows the topics incredibly well but the organization of the class is a big barrier to being able to learn. Theres a discord/github/canvas all with important materials for the class but if you can get past that hes great.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Online Savvy

comment: Maybe somewhat disorganized, but he really cares about what he does. He has a wealth of knowledge and you will learn a lot if you give it a chance.

I love Dov. Yes things like files and homeworks were disorganized and in different locations, but I learned a lot from his lectures and office hours. He really cares and is a VERY generous person. By far my favorite professor and I don't know why he gets such a bad rep.
gets a bad rap but in reality has a lot of knowledge to spare. people who get mad at him cannot take criticism for the life of them, just go to lecture, take notes, and dont question the feedback.

Dov's class is a disorganized, lazy mess. His canvas/github/google drive are insanely disorganized and formatted horribly. His lectures are long, disorganized rambles with 10 minutes of content per class. Labs are the hardest part of the class and are only worth 10% of your grade. Class is not hard Dov just does not want to be inconvenienced ever

thought it'd be scarier but it was eh. lots of extra credit opportunities tho tests weigh heavily in grading. hws & labs were disorganized. often, he bails from office hrs. he can get sidetracked during lectures and is not the best at explaining. kruger's not teaching 390 anymore so hopefully, the new professor isn't worse but the bar has been low.
Good professor, not your friend.
Horrible professor. Lack of organization, effort to care for his students' performances in his classes, and open-mindedness. This class has been one of the worst classes I've ever taken at Stevens.

The most disorganized person I've met in my life. DSA course was just him typing on a google doc from memory and showing code. We had only 3 homework assignments and they were strange. Comes up with curriculum changes on the spot and then forgets about them. Tests had errors. Goes off on random tangents. Sometimes gives cool facts. Energetic guy.

Imagine having no slide or references for class, instead relying on him hopefully remembering to emphasize everything you need to know. Trying to read through the Google Drive notes outside of class is like trying to read Chinese, it is horrifically disorganized and can really only be accompanied by him explaining everything between hourly rants.
Oh boy Dov, what a funny man. He is such a cool dude, and he genuinely loves what he's doing, even if he's learning it with us.

One of the worst professors I have ever had to be with. This man cannot teach for the life of him. Everything is disorganized, the classes barely understand what is going on. And this specific course focuses way too much on assembly programming instead of actual microprocessor architecture. Avoid at all cost

Professor Kruger's class is a mess. Disorganized and the lectures are just him writing code and talking about it. Professor is extremely hard to reach, unprofessional, and lashed out at the students several times during the semester. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Always typing on lecture instead of sufficient preparation. The storage of files is a mess (both google drive and github). Why not download free e-books and attend public classes? Learn by yourself even better than waste time on this course.
No slides, No logical on lecture. Just write something on Google Docs, so that it hard to follow sometimes. Lots of programming homework, but homework part just take 5% on whole credits.

Dov Kruger is one of the few professors at Stevens I go out of my way to take classes with, even if it means a large increase in my workload. He is amazingly knowledgeable on the subject of computers and programming, and eagerly opens himself to his students after class. His lectures are fast-paced and informative, with a focus on practical usage.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: He seems very smart and unprepared at the same time for each class, which means it's hard to follow his class and his code is not clear. And the lecture material is not well sorted, it's all over the place in his google drive. You'd better to attend every class and take detail notes so that you would know which part will be on the quiz and exams.

In all fairness the ECE department recently lost a very important person, and Dov Kruger tried his best to fill in his shoes. That being said, the class was overall a trainwreck. No organization to the class whatsoever, works fast and talks fast but makes a ton of mistakes along the way. I pray to all EE and CPE majors that the class improves soon.

Do not take his classes. He doesn't grade assignments till the end of the semester and is very unprepared for his classes as he often goes to wikipedia and read stuff from there. He also doesn't teach that well and is hard to talk to
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Actually, no need to attend his courses. You can learn it all by yourself. You should think twice before select his courses.
I wish my money spent on a more qualified professor than him.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--TEST HEAVY

comment: He's a great educator! He knows what he has to teach in each lecture. He doesn't use slides, he makes a google document and records his lecture as it happens, so you can refer to it later. Paying attention in his class is important, otherwise you could do bad in a test. He makes you a good coder, even if you don't get a good grade.

Dov is a terrific professor, and is dedicated to his students actually grasping the material. He often expresses the importance of the material and its relevance in real world applications. He explains code in a way that is very clear for beginners, yet still useful for others. Great programming professors are rare, so get in his class if you can.

Really good professor for CAL103 that gives really good feedback on essays. He gives you more freedom on essays that a lot of other 103 professors but I think the focus on "discourse community" got a little old for me. But definitely would recommend him for 103

He was definitely one of my best teachers this semester. He gives extensions if you need them, and he encourages you with positive feedback. He is a very understanding teacher and is very easy to communicate with. Amazing teacher and I would've taken him again for CAL105 but there were no more spots.

Middleton is one of the better professors wanting all his students to succeed, which is why he gives you chances to redo assignments for a better grade. He has high standards but truly helps with reaching them. He has clear guidelines and expectations and shows examples help his students improve and give the best work they can.

Awesome Prof. Fun topics and has an amazing sense of empathy for his students. Billy will give you the chance to do better and really gives you shots at learning while still getting a good grade. CHOOSE BILLY FOR CLASSES! He is one of the best at Stevens.

Professor Middleton gave great feedback and set clear expectations. His lectures always connected directly to what we were doing in class, and he utilized class discussions to keep things interesting. He's a fair grader, and if you put in the effort you'll get the grade you deserve.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I took both his 103 and 105 CAL classes, he's great definitely one of the better CAL professors. Gives great feedback on essays, just ask him questions if you don't know something. He is super kind and my 105 class was actually very fun (we learned about superheroes). There are a lot of bad professors at Stevens, so cherish the good ones.
Professor Middleton is the best. He cares a lot about his students and wants everyone to succeed. Be prepared to participate in class. He is a fair grader and I enjoyed his class a lot.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I had Billy for CAL103 and 105. His teaching changed my writing so much--and all for the better. He gives interesting and relevant lectures, interesting assignments, and excellent feedback; I always felt comfortable reaching out to get his thoughts on my writing before submission. He really cares about his students and the material. A swell guy!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: I had Professor Middleton for CAL 103 during the crazy fall 2020 semester. Despite the challenges of remote learning, Professor Middleton always made sure everybody understood assignments, was very approachable, and has a great sense of humor. Lectures were engaging and inclusive. I am so glad to have him again for CAL 105 in the spring.

Professor Middleton is one of the best instructors I've ever had. I'm a current student of his and he always makes sure everyone understands what's going on. Gives amazing feedback on your essay so you know what to fix and what you're doing right. Super nice man and available whenever you may need help.
Professor Middleton is a great teacher. He gives excellent feedback and the workload was very reasonable.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: If you want to actually learn and engage in your mandatory English classes this is the professor to take, uses Socratic method meaning you talk more than he does but still a lot of good learning, great and useful presentations on writing, actually interesting topics to write essays on. Highly recommend.
Talk to him and he'll work with you on whatever the issue is: be whether it is caused by academics or not
Great professor who is tough grader, but gives great feedback and lets you make changes to previous work for a better grade.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: One of my favorite professors this year, I used to hate writing, now not so much. He provides excellent feedback that actually improves your writing and he is a reasonable grader. He grades his essays harder than the assignments but he offers one revision at the end of the semester and if you use his feedback you will do well. Lectures are engaging

Middleton is not the 103 professor to take if you want an easy A, but if you actually want to learn to be a better writer, there's no one better.  And if you come to his office hours, he'll tell you exactly how to write a winning paper.

The midterms and the finals are a joke, but he is a harsh grader but wants you to revise the essays. This is the biggest drawback of the class just because he wants you to basically start from scratch and revise the essay if you did bad on it. Since I was busy during the semester it was hard to revise :(
Very good professor! You can tell he prepares for every class carefully. But still a lot of work.
I scheduled to meet after class for help with him multiple times and got stood up twice.  He is a very hard grader when it comes to essays.  I am not a good writer and, so this class kills me.

After a terrible string of high school English teachers, Professor Middleton finally taught me how to write. Great guy, great teacher, 2-hour lectures drag on a bit but overall I learned a lot. Only complaint is that participation is mandatory and a lot of the time I just don't have anything to say.

He gave us plenty of time to finish assignments and opportunities to come to him for help.  One of the few profs who actually keeps office hours.  He gives you the option to revise papers and yes he expects you to learn, but isn't that what we're here for?  If you want to learn how to write, you'll love this guy.  If you're lazy, you won't.

I took a creative writing class with Dr. Billy a few years ago.  I'm not a great writer but he made the class very easy and loads of fun.  He really made me want to keep writing and try to get better.

He sends out assignments the night before they're due. He gave out an assignment the night before he wanted it due after we had two weeks off. Also takes forever to grade essays. Fails people on their essays because "no essay is perfect" and he wants you to go back and revise your essay so you can learn. Wish I didn't sign up for this guy.

Very knowledgeable about the subjects we read about in class and he expects you to be  as well.  Classroom discussions are fun, but you have to participate or he'll take points off your grade, so sometime it's stressful if you don't have anything smart to say.  He's a tough grader on first drafts of papers, but you get to revise, so it's all good.

Tough grader, but extremely helpful. He teaches you exactly what he wants in terms of work quality. You will write a lot, but your writing will also improve a lot. Class was generally very interesting.
Good teacher.

Tough prof, but his class is a lot of fun and he's really engaging and interesting.  Expect to write A LOT but as others have said at least you get to choose your topic.  Overall, one of the best teachers at Stevens.

Middleton is a great professor. He is always willing to help students out. He is clear with his lectures and cares about his students' grades. He wants them to do well and is also very entertaining in class. He allows revisions for your papers which really helps boost your grade. Take advantage of that and you will do much better than I did.

He is very clear when lecturing and assigns essays so that everyone gets to choose what they write about. I liked this since I was actually interested in what I was writing about. He is also a very fair grader.
Very tough but fair grader, and a nice guy.  Gives lots of comments on papers and tries really hard to help you become a better writer.
Difficult grader, but altogether worthwhile. Super easy to talk to and actually cares about your concerns and tries to help. Good stuff
BEST CAL TEACHER

Not an easy freebie by any means but definitely a great professor.  I had very low expectations for the class but Prof. Middleton really made the class worth while.  He will help you get the most out of this class.

Professor Middleton's CAL 103 class is harder than compared to all of the other Stevens CAL 103 Professors. However, you do become a better writer, but at the cost of excess work. He is also a very strict grader on the essays you have to write for the class. His assignment sheets for essays or assignments are very long and difficult to understand.
Best CAL 103 teacher.

Very helpful, Professor Middleton is new to Stevens and has proven himself to be an amazing English professor. A teacher who understands academic struggle and is willing to help a student out with an assignment when necessary.

Very nice, slow paced, and good examples in class. Everything is so easy it is genuinely hard to not get an A in this class. He uploads all the past years exams (over 10 years worth of exams) and his new exams are mostly the same as the past exams, either he exactly reuses the same question or he only slightly changes it.

The class was solely graded on exams with a final exam. The course material was essentially just memorization and conceptual, but not difficult. Professor Russ is accessible by email and is genuinely very helpful; if you notice any discrepancies on an exam, he will regrade it for you thoroughly. Class is very good to understand for coding and logic
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Russ is good and will try to help everyone succeed to do better in his classes. He teaches examples and less theory. He uploads all practice exams and gives ample responses. He is however a harsh grader and is not very generous with partial credit so beware. Finally, he will curve at the end but you don't see your current standing. Meh
love him. take the class. full package.

He's a pretty funny guy although lectures can be a bit dry here and there. He gives a good amount of homework and tests but it's all doable since it's basically all the worked examples in lecture and on canvas. Would totally recommend taking him.
Professor Russ is one of the best math professors I ever had. He is awesome! Take Professor Russ for MA 222 if you have the option.

Easy class anyway, but it all doesn't even matter because during exams he just lets anyone sit anywhere and doesn't really proctor so you could literally just have a test squad that shows up to the 4 exams and not come ever again. If you do participate, he has really good slides and is hilarious in class anyway. But if you're lazy, yk.

Easily the best professor I have had at Stevens. Unlike most other math professors who put great emphasis on theory, he actually works through examples mainly. This makes the class so much easier since you actually know how to do the work. Very test heavy but as long as you do the practice tests it will be a breeze.

One of the best and most well-respected professors you'll come across. Has a great grading scheme and usually adds a curve at the end of the semester. You won't know your grades until the semester ends, which is about the only bad thing I could say about Russ. Extremely caring and wants everyone to do well. Just study past exams and you'll be good.

Had prof Russ for probability and statistics and I enjoyed his class. Tests are worth a lot of the grade, but he posts previous years tests online with solutions to study for, and the exam questions are always pretty similar. Homeworks aren't too bad as long as you go to class and take notes. He's super nice and actually cares about us.

Prof Russ is great, lectures are sometimes really boring. But, all the tests are available to you so doing well relies on doing a lot of practice tests. Prof is very caring but sometimes goes extremely slow in class because of this.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Hands down the best MA222 Professor at Stevens. Great explanations in every lecture, super engaging and held review sessions for every test/quiz we had. Also provided hw/quiz problems from previous years that we could study from, so that was a huge plus.

Great guy, but his lectures were sometimes droning. Homework is kind of long, but reflects very well on the tests. ABUNDANT online resources, especially with a pdf textbook. Past tests with worked out answers are posted and are amazing practice. Don't need to attend lectures to do very well.

Great lectures, great assignments, great exams - Russ has it all. As long as you take the lectures as well as the assignments seriously, you should be set for the class. For the exams, he provides you with plenty of practice so that you are prepared which sort of justifies his tough grading. Highly recommend!

Professor Russ is the best! Literally the funniest and nicest person ever. Lectures can be dry sometimes but he's so caring and will always do his best to help out. If you have him, attend lectures and pay attention! You will pass if you practice the exams and do the homework. He really wants everyone to pass and know the material.
Such a nice teacher, really helpful and makes statistics way more manageable. Also always available if you need help. Study hard for the tests though because they are worth a lot
Great professor who breaks down the material for students to understand

He's a real nice guy who cares if we pass, and I had him when we are all online but he would have review sessions before every test and make past tests available for studying. Also, he gets sad when no one talks to him, so he likes when you participate
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Simply a great lecturer and approachable guy. I would gladly take his classes again.

Larry Russ is a fantastic professor who is practical and caring for his students. He does an amazing job adapting to online learning for COVID and tests are similar to questions given in homework and previous course's tests.
Such a kind warm-hearted person and an excellent teacher

Professor Russ is one of the best professors in the math department. His lectures are boring but only because he spends so much time making sure everybody understands the topics. His office hours are great and he gives loads of practice problems before tests. He grades on a bell curve so it's not too hard to get an A. I highly recommend him!
He teaches extremely clearly and communicates concepts very well. He goes over lots of example problems and shows all the concepts clearly in use. Overall he teaches really well and he's really nice.
Amazing professor that really cares about his students

Smart, nice and charismatic professor! I took statistics 10 years ago in a different school and hated it but this time with Professor Russ I loved it! I don't understand how some students skip his lectures. He is the smartest man and you're lucky to be in the room. Lots of homework. Hard exams but similar to the previous years. Curves the grade.

Lots of people skip class, but try to go to every lecture. If you have any questions, he's really approachable. Even though his exams are hard, just study lecture notes and previous exams. Final grades are based on the bell curve, so do well on exams. No doubt that he's a good guy, but I also agree lectures are dry.

Big Larry is your classic math professor that maintained his teaching ways from decades ago. Lectures are boring but they're not confusing at all and teach content well. Take homework seriously, practice exams very seriously. He also gives little/no partial credit on exams; aim for 100 on the final. Finally, his tongue. You'll be amazed.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Tough grader

comment: He's one of the best professor for me at Stevens. He's course is quite tough but he teaches really good if you pay attention in class. He's respectful as well. And he's nice too. I'll definitely recommend this professor.

He provides easy-to-solve problems in class, but his tests have harder questions on them. Be sure to review those past quizzes otherwise you will not be as successful in his class. Also, he'll call on students in class randomly, so be prepared for that.

I have a love/hate relationship with Larry. His lectures are very boring and long. His homeworks are tough but designed to make you understand how to apply the concepts he teaches. He rarely gives partial credit on exams which are 90% of the grade. I learned a lot, but mostly on my own time  not from him. The final is like the old exams he posts.

All the others students complaining just have not paid attention. The answers to the homework are basically in his lecture notes which are posted online, and exams are not much harder than the homework. 10/10, 11/10 when he gets snarky.

He is a very good teacher. He goes over many examples in class and uploads all of his notes for you to refer to. As long as you GO TO CLASS, it is easy to learn the material and learn it well. He's also a very nice guy and easy to talk to/ask questions.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: He uploads his lecture notes online and goes slow enough in class to make sure people understand. If you go to class or read the notes you should pass without an issue.
Like him as a person. As a professor. No. Jut avoid his classes, your GPA will go lower. Take his class with other professors.
I just wouldn't take another class with him. NO

This professor is not easy going, won't try to work with you if you fail the classes sadly i.e make up tests. Very rigid. Class notes are easy, assignments are harder and the exams are even much more x10 harder than everything which is so annoying. I wouldn't take this class or any with him ever again.

AVOID THIS PROFESSOR AND CLASS IF POSSIBLE! Offers absolutely no help when students ask about homework questions and does not give partial credit on exams.  Lost 40 points on a test because I did not multiply an answer by 4.  Lectures and notes are difficult to understand and he does not seem to have a good grasp of the material he is teaching.

The problems he solves in the class are easy. You tend to understand them well. Class notes are handwritten and often scribbled, so it makes it very difficult to understand what exactly is mentioned there. The content is brilliant though. The homework questions are tough & are completely unrelated to the class problems. Exams are even more complex.

As a dean of students, he's a fantastic guy. As a probstats professor, not so much. The exam questions are way more complex than the homework questions...which are paraphrased from the book anyway. There's no doubt he knows his stuff, but it seems like he thinks we know our stuff, too.
Miller was often boring and got flustered in lectures, easier to learn the content on your own. He cared about student success and was available outside of class.
had him for MA 125/126. Took attendance sometimes. I never showed up. Went to Serbin's lectures instead. The way he teaches is boring.

Boring and dry professor with lectures that make no sense. The actual material for the exams seemed much easier than whatever it was he was teaching. Do not recommend because you will end up just teaching yourself everything.

A lot of people don't like this professor. He is pretty good if you pay attention and listen in class. If you have questions and ask for recommendations, he's more than happy to give them to you. He also records all of his lectures so you can watch them if you miss them. He isn't great at responding to emails -- you can just email other profs

Patrick Miller was by far my favorite professor at Stevens. His lectures are very easy to understand and he goes into very intense proofs for 30 minutes before being corrected by someone. He also has a hearing problem so when you talk to him you have to basically shout at him and just pray that he understands your question. 10/10 professor.

A lot of tests and a lot of homework. Professor Miller tries his best to teach a hard class, but no matter how, it still comes off boring. WebEx assignments are unfair and only stimulate students to cheat because of the limited attempts they have. Some of the tests felt unfair because of their grading. The class should definitely be curved.

Miller is genuinely the worst professor I have ever had. He was a horrible lecturer, tough grader, never gave any feedback,  took days to respond to emails, and communicated updates about assignments extremely last minute (think 9pm the day before they were due at 9am). Try to avoid him at all costs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Prof. Miller's lack of enthusiasm is infectious. You'll learn more from the homework assignments and recitations than you'll ever be able to learn from sitting through his lectures.

I've had him twice and I can say he is a good teacher. Super lecture heavy, I don't reccomened missing a class, but even if you do his Canvas page is super organized and he posts plently of notes per each lecture. He is also very accomadating e.g. if you want to take a test on a diffrent day. Grading isn't too harsh either.

I won't repeat what was previously said about his lectures, as it is true. However, there are positives: his class is extremely well organized and there are many chances to grasp the material before the assessments. There are better teachers, but Miller is excellent at making sure the TAs are in sync with the lectures to fully help students.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Assignments are posted late, homework is not graded until the end of the semester, and grades are not posted until after the semester ends. He doesn't post exam material until the day before the exam and his exams are not graded equally. He is always late to class and most of the lecture is useless. Be prepared to teach yourself and still do badly.

Honestly, not as hard of a class as I thought.  Eigenvalues were the only thing I was truly confounded about but I understood him the rest of the time.  He's really proof heavy and rarely brings out examples for us to comprehend.  People don't come in lectures and they're the ones that complain about how hard the class is.

Patty Miller's class is genuinely not worth showing up for. He will probably show up late, and will show you some random proof that will not help you with anything related to the tests or homework. I learned everything in this class through recitation and external tools, lecture is actually worthless don't go to it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: This class absolutely sucked. Out of the three professors, Miller is definitely the best. It is nearly impossible to reach Miller outside of class. You have to show up (pay attention!!) , work hard and collaborate with others to pass the class. Respect the difficulty of the material and you should be ok.

Professor Miller is a very nice person, but he is unable to explain things in more than one way. If his method doesn't work for you, asking him to reexplain in a different way isn't really an option. He is very kind and genuinely wants you to do well.

Dr. Miller is not the best lecturer but he def understands the content. Diff EQ is a lot of work though and will require effort on your end to work with others in your class to succeed. Miller is also a very fair professor, I had many emergencies and he was very accommodating with due dates which I've heard not many professors always are.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Miller will show up late and start muttering, so sit up front. He will go through a lecture without pause, usually a proof, run out of time at the end, and awkwardly stop talking. You have to do a lot of work on your own to master this class if you're not a DiffEq expert. Exam grading can run the gamut. He is hard to get a hold of outside of class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Lectures are very confusing and extremely difficult to follow.

Miller is a nice guy but he cant teach. He'll spend most of the lecture explaining a proof for a topic, and then runs out of time and never gives actual examples, so you don't have anything to go off of when you do hw. He assumes that you know everything, so his explanations dont make sense. But hey he's always willing to help during office hours.

A low voice so a front seat is more or less needed to be attentive. His notes are good through independent study but the presentation of them in lecture is usually shaky at best. Exams are graded VERY leniently in terms of partial credit, Slader/Chegg helps you complete WebAssign, workshops are sometimes usual, and past exams will save you.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Nice guy but his lectures are really boring and he's never on time
He just reads his notes during class, which is very unhelpful. Lectures to you as if you are experts on Diff Eq, and doesn't explain anything at all. You'll be teaching yourself in the class

Super cool guy. Really cares about students and is always willing to make sure you understand things. Didn't think he was an unclear lecturer at all, honestly just try not to sit in the back. Wish he did more examples in class. But otherwise always clear and concise.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: You better be down for lectures, kid, because if you have P Mills for multivariate calculus, you're going to be going to each and every one. They are not mandatory, but the material is fast and furious. Miller tries his best to relay the information to you, but sometimes gets too hung up on examples over teaching material. He will never be on time.

Miller is the type of professor who comes to class, albeit often a hair late, super-prepared and ready to start teaching. It's non-stop note scribbling for a full 50 minutes (and don't you dare miss a class -- the handouts aren't much help without him there), but he makes Differential Equations, a difficult concept, very comprehensible.
Low voice, boring lectures, If half of the class fails a test there is something wrong in the professor, pulled all nighters to study and that worked best.

Surpassing any other teacher in clarity, well-developed explanations and kind iron patience. If you ask him about one point, he will give you the entire picture. Not true that his voice is unclear, I am a foreign student and understand him perfectly well.  He was able to help me a lot with Prob Stats also for the summer, outside his own course.

If you have a question, he'll answer it.  He does enough examples in class.  But he's too quiet in lectures with roughly 30 students or more, and sometimes makes mistakes without catching himself.  Plus, I had AP Calc BC in high school, so I went into this class with a degree of familiarity with the material.
his voice is not clear.
Awful Professor, switch out ASAP

P.Millz...  If the class average is 63, and this guy is the director of that department, then a lot is to be said about this man.  His voice is low and unclear, so you can barely hear him, let alone learn from him. His modules are quite difficult and (in my opinion) pointless and only more ways to hurt your grade. You have to study HARD to pass
I hate this man.

Why oh why didn't I credit out of that class!  I put the blame on the torture on the class not only on him, but on having to take Maz's tests without being prepared, and the stevens registrar that thought <b>8:00AM calc</b> was a good idea.
As the class median average is slighty above failing, I can only conclude that he hates happiness and may be a vampire of some sort.

He is the worst professor ever.  He does not even look at you when he teaches and he is never there for help.  He makes up the final exams and he makes it on purpose to allow students to do poorly.  This is true because I have spoken and drank with other professors who hate him as well.

The MA 121-126 classes are all difficult and fast-paced, regardless of the professor. I have had Serbin for all 4 classes. Serbin's lectures are detailed, and he gives plenty of examples. He does have a pretty thick Russian accent, but I have never struggled to understand him. Overall, I would definitely recommend him as a professor!

Without getting into much, Denis Serbin is a professor who gives their info very clearly in lectures, but it's paced way too quickly, and grading on tests is especially harsh. This is a weed-out class if I've ever seen one, and the tough bar of understanding combined with a very thick accent makes gaining information fairly difficult.
Heavy accent. Lectures for 121 were perfect, lectures for 122 were unfocused and lackluster. Expected to be self taught.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Serbin is a great lecturer but sometimes explains concepts in a way that's hard to follow if you're not already familiar with calculus. He's good to take if you're already familiar with the material from high school and the homework, tests, and quizzes are identical for all sections.

What a guy. A little hard to understand his lectures because they are heavily theoretical. But, what a guy. I encouraged a lot of my friends that didn't have Serbin to pull up and they simply did not regret it.
All round good professor.

Prof Serbin is great. Loved and enjoyed his lectures a lot. Abstract algebra is a difficult class but he made things very easy to follow and taught everything you need to know for exams. Highly recommend.

Professor Serbin is a fantastic teacher. He teaches in a very effective style, covering all the material that is on the tests in class, so if you just pay attention in class, you don't need to study much for his tests. Only complaint is that the tests are usually quite difficult, with some questions being way too hard for no reason.
great professor and attendance isn't mandatory so that was really good

Professor Serbin genuinely cares for all of his students. He is among the best lecturers: he always handwrites everything, so it is much easier to follow along and understand the intuition behind concepts instead of flying through pre-written digital notes. Grading for MA121-126 is identical for all profs. He's underrated on here b/c of class rigor
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Solid teacher, nothing special but he will definitely get you through the class.

Everyone talks about the accent and how Russian he but that, while true, becomes irrelevant after you familiarize yourself with the class. The lectures were always very informative and he usually reserves the last 10 or so minutes at the end of class to go over material for quizzes. The exams are closer to the HW and recitation. 122 is harder.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: MA 122 was certainly harder than MA 121, but it's possible to get an A. Make sure you understand the early concepts, as they are vital for your success later in the course. Serbin can sometimes be confusing with his explanations behind things, but it's only because he likes to teach the concepts fully. Very fair professor, and class!

He is a knowledgeable and caring professor that he will never say no to a question no matter how dumb it is. His lectures were informative and tries his absolute best to draw visuals that helped me a lot to understand easily. Most dumb students procrastinate and then blame it on the prof. accent. Be prepared and practice every two days at least.
Useless classes, you have to learn every thing by ur self, what he showed on class will not exist on test
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Prof. Serbin was a good professor for MA 121. His lectures were straight forward and informative, but he often waits until the last 10 minutes or so to cover topics that show up on quizzes. The quizzes are mostly conceptual questions while the exams are more like the homework/recitation problems. If you put in the work, you can get an A. Good luck!
Always on time, always prepared for the lecture. Gives students time to ask questions. He knows and loves what hes doing. Class was easy but you always have to do your part as well.
good class, good lectures
Clear and concise lectures. Explains everything clearly and answers all the questions. Very helpful during his office hours. Quickly replies emails even late or on weekends

The accent doesn't really matter, you get used to it after the first few classes. The problem is he goes really fast in his lectures, and he doesn't really turn around, so questions get missed. His lectures are very dry and he isn't very good at explaining the topics. His office hours are amazing though, go to those if you are stuck
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Awesome professor! He explains everything very well, giving many examples. Always ready to help. He's fun and nice and loves what he's doing. Accessible during his office hours. Would def take his class again.

Accent isn't that bad as long as you pay attention. Seems to be the best calc professor from the general consensus, really knowledgeable guy. Always willing to work with you and answer questions, and down for a good joke.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Denis Serbin's knowledge is profoundly deep. Any question you can think of, he has a well reasoned answer for. His writing skills are top-notch, and he takes things step-by-step; you could be deaf and follow the lecture just from the whiteboard. He takes criticism well. The only possible issue: he has a Russian accent, which is just fine for me.

Not a bad guy, but his lectures were really boring that it made it difficult to sit through. Every day he'd walk into class one minute late - never early, never on time, never later. He wasn't mean and you can tell he really knows his stuff. Sometimes it's hard to understand him due to his accent, but not terrible if you pay attention.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I made an account just so I could leave positive feedback for Professor Serbin. Yes, he has an accent, but after the first week it becomes irrelevant. Professor Serbin knows what he is talking about and can actually provide explanation to your questions. He also makes himself pretty accessible out of class as well. Love this guy!!
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures--Would take again

comment: Fairly thick accent, but if you concentrate enough it's easy to get used to. It's obvious that he knows his stuff, but sometimes he had issues trying to explain it to the class. Very sweet and always ready to answer questions, you just need to focus on what he's writing on the board to truly get what he's saying.
Don't know why more people don't love this guy. Best calculus teacher in the department, and truly cares about his students. Little hard to understand but it is not an issue.
Lectures are very clear and example problems are helpful. MA123 is difficult, but if you go to class and give an effort you can do well.
His lectures were not that difficult to understand after you got used to his accent.  Tried to help when you asked a question, but was often unable to give you helpful answers.
Gave wrong notes, not a fan, never want to go to class
Good professor. His accent's not that bad.
Knowledgeable individual...but very hard to understand with his  accent. Nice guy, but not recommended for this course.
He's not bad once you get used to his accent. He'll help you out when you ask questions and hes not too bad.

He is very russian and can't understand a word he says. If you want to ask a question it's very hard because he rarely faces the class. He seems to always be facing the board, which also doesn't help in understanding him. When you do get your question he either explains it very poorly or explains something that you didn't even ask.
"In principle:" -Literally the only words I hear in this class.
Didn't like the class
I enjoyed her lectures and the course. She looks for student feedback throughout the semester, and is generous with giving extra credit on tests. I would definitely take one of her courses again.

Professor Terolli is a fantastic professor in spite of her slightly strict grading. Her tests are easy and have similar questions to the assignments/slides. Office hours were very helpful during the assignments. She gives lots of materials to practice, which makes preparing for tests so much easier. She also gives many chances to boost your grade.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I didn't like the class and didn't attend it after session 5 or maybe 6. Honestly, it felt like you could just learn everything by reading the lecture notes at home and there wasn't any extra in the class. And It's a bit surprising to see lots of good reviews about this class.

The curriculum is good; however, her teaching approach doesn't foster engagement or enthusiasm for the subject. She tends to deliver lectures with the aim of rushing through them, rather than creating an environment that encourages curiosity and deeper understanding. Assignments are time-consuming. I'd recommend exploring other teachers.

Considering the nature of the class, I think Terolli was a good teacher! She uses a lot of visual examples and makes the information easy to understand. Homework and Labs come in frequently, as well as pop quizzes, but none felt too overwhelming. She can sometimes lose control of her lectures, but apart from that she makes the content very clear.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: She is a very tough grader and has much more difficult exams/homeworks in comparison to other professors. I don't think Terolli is necessarly a bad professor I just believe that it is signifcantly harder to do well in her course in comparison to others. Trust me I wouldn't be wasting time writing this review if it wasn't true.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: This is your most important class, you are a cs major. It will be hard. Homework/labs will take hours because they are not clear on how to solve and its okay because you are supposed to learn from these hurdles. The TA are pretty helpful but try not to rely on them for every small problem. Review her material that she posts for every week.

Lots of homework, you have to do every week. The TA teach you not the professor. And just follow the PPT. Don't have example for your homework. And you have to use Latex to do the homework. So the homework is tough. If you choose this course, you have to spend lots of time to learn the course by yourself. So awful experience.
Course was little difficult but Learnt a lot from it. I was able to apply the knowledge in my future ML courses

Attendance was optional, and I can skip if I wanted too. BUT I still went to her lectures because I actually learned alot and found her lectures useful. Her lessons are very clear and she makes learning CS concepts understandable. I had a little bit of python experience, but I still learned alot in her class!
rating_tags: Participation matters--EXTRA CREDIT--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: She's the sweetest and most caring professor ever! I loved her class, she cleared out the math concepts that had confused me for years. This class is a must-take! She's a slightly tough grader and her tests can be slightly challenging, but she gives plenty of opportunity to catch up if you have a bad grade.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I was really scared coming into this course. But I was in good hands with Professor Terolli. She was a very generous grader, gave a lot of extra credit, and even bumped our grades up at the end! She was always there to help us and her review sessions were very helpful for the exams, some questions were almost identical! She gave us candy too!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: A bit hard to understand at first but very good otherwise.
Good and clear lectures, really sets foundation for future ML related courses.

You won't find a professor that cares more about their students' success. Dr. Terolli gives ample opportunity to be successful in this course. A word of caution on CS 556 though, it's a tough, very fast-paced course. If you know you'll be taking this course, and aren't strong on math, you must self-study linear algebra, and differentiation.

Fantastic professor. CS115 is a difficult intro course if you are coming into it with no previous coding knowledge, but Professor Terolli makes it manageable. Her lectures are very clear as well as interactive, and she makes herself very available outside of class. It's clear she cares for her students, with extra office hours and reviews for exams
Great professor. Cares about the students and improving the class. Would definitely recommend.

Professor Terolli class is great in terms of the content and the meterial we have to cover. However, she tends to be very rude sometimes. She focuses too much on grades rather than makes learning a fun experience.
Learned a lot in this course and was very happy with Terolli's teaching. Very much so reccomend!

If you're scared coming into CS from high school, and manage to get a class with Terolli, rest assured that you got lucky and she will definitely take care of your doubts as she is a phenomenal teacher who will help you genuinely learn and makes class enjoyable. Undoubtedly the best CS 115 teacher you could ask for!!!

Prof Terolli is an amazing lecturer. She explains concepts in a fun manner with a few jokes here and there. All you need to do is read her slides and with a little bit of work, you can easily pass with an A grade. She is a lenient grader too.

Professor Terolli is absolutely amazing, definitely the best CS115 teacher at Stevens. She genuinely cares about her students understanding the material and will go above and beyond to make sure that every single person in the classroom feels comfortable. In my opinion, she is everything a CS professor should be. Kudos, Terolli!

Prof. Erisa Terolli tries her best that her students understand the concepts taught in the class and also is an amazing grader. Just attend the classes, refer the material provided, and practice a little bit (after all its a Maths course) and you can easily get an A (highest grade). Assignments are also easy. Beware of pop quizzes!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Prof. Terolli is a great professor who has done a great job teaching her first semester at Stevens. She is well-spoken and knows how to clearly convey what she is talking about to the class, and she gives many opportunities for office hours, help, and extra credit. Overall, she's a caring professor who actually wants her students to pass.

It's obvious by the way that she teaches that Terolli is incredibly intelligent AND she is fantastic at explaining concepts. I wish she could teach me every single class. She's also a super kind grader and very accessible for extra help. Also very generous with extra credit. I've never heard anything bad about her.
Literally an amazing professor, so good at explaining problems, a very kind grader. The best CS 115 professor at stevens
She is very funny and caring.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Professor Terolli truly wants each and every one of her students to succeed. The course is somewhat challenging to students without prior experience, but she is happy to go over anything you have questions about. Very approachable and a great professor!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Professor Terolli is very passionate about the subject and her students, she genuinely cares about each and every student and is very helpful in understanding the course material and making sure everyone understands the ideas.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Professor Terolli is just amazing! Possibly the best professor at Stevens. It's easy to see that she really cares about her students and their understanding of the subject. She explains the concepts over and over again until you understand them.

Professor Terolli is an absolutely amazing teacher! She's down to earth and explains everything in a story-telling way that makes easy sense. She explains very basic logic and never puts someone down for not knowing. As someone who is coding for the first time, I am so glad to have her as my first coding teacher.
Funny, knowledgeable, and professional. Would take again!
Fun class
None better!
Inspirational!
eally helped set my career goals.
Realistic perspective on how to prepare for a successful career.
Makes you think and change your perspective.
A lot of work, but well worth it.
Career changing...
The course made me change my outlook on my career.  Technology is important, but a balance of business/management is essential.
Provides a realistic challenging learning experience.

Jerry is a renowned expert in information technology and business alignment and I've benefited tremendously by his counsel, leadership, insights and applied experience in this key area.  He is an invaluable reference in my role as an IT executive.
I can say with all sincerity, I would not be where I am today without programs like GIIM.

he courses and leadership under Jerry allowed me to transition from the corporate world into the academic world. His IBM experience and connections with IT leaders from around the world were invaluable in developing a research stream that not only resulted in my Ph.D. dissertation, but several co-authored articles over the years. Luftman's guidance

The classes prepared me for significantly increased responsibilities in my company.  Within 2 years of completing the courses I was responsible for strategically critical areas of our global technical infrastructure
As part of my corporate education program, this course prepared me for my new job as a middle manger.
Changed my perspective on my career to recognize the importance of non-technical considerations and how to address them.
A lot of work, but well worth the experience.
If you want an easy course, this is not it. But, if you want to learn something valuable, go for it.
Best ever!!!
He is a tough professor but you will learn a great deal from this class. I had my doubts about taking the class but don't regret it for a second. It was a LOT of work but it was worth it!
He impose his ideas on students

He is something else, a memorable, bombastic man.  Years after leaving Stevens, he is one of the professors I still remember well.  And yes, he does make people cry.  So do senior executives at times, the business world is not always a warm and fuzzy place.  Sometimes communication problems will hold you back, better to learn it in school.

Not at all clear on the expectations about assignments and presentations. Very inconsistent with remarks. A lot of crude comments and jokes which are not at all appropriate for the class. Just want to show-off and create an image as if he is the toughest professor in the block. Bottom line – I don’t think I got much out of his class.
Very autocratic!

I think he is lacking in some areas so he has to be loud, obnoxious and raw.  I wanted to kill myself after the first day with all of the assignments, but the best class was when we had to give a CEO presentation.  He made people cry, but that is when I learned that is when I shine best.  Bring it on Jerry Boy.
Condescending, Rude, Arrogant - Just like real world CEO's. 14 Week Crash Course on dealing with higher echelon in the corporate, and surviving.

Great orator, brilliant person, scholarly mind, shrewd business thinking...but will not care about anything but him, and rudeness is like a second nature to him...but a person worth experience if you can stand his tough words...
Very bad

Arrogant, Disrespectful, Excellent lecturer, Unclear on assignment requirements.  Will destroy you on your presentation (seriously to the point where students that can't take it will cry).  Great learning experience.  Just remember KISS and you should be fine.
Prepares you for the real world in his own imtimidating arrogant way.  His style was not for me.

Arrogant& makes some cutting remarks-does NOT take well to people who don't have their ducks lined up. Instructions sometimes fuzzy. BUT a great lecturer& gets VERY important real world points across--listen closely! especially to the tough world message.
Great professor who effectively prepares you for what you'll face in real-world IT/IS management.
Briliant professor, however very arrogant & judgemental, need to work on respect
Great Teacher! Arrogant at times, but deserves to be. The man is brilliant!

Class is very unorganized overall. Professor doesn't even have the syllabus posted and its almost the end of the semester. He reads off the textbook, cannot understand and tests are impossible to study for. He tells you to study certain chapters e.g "chapters 6-9" but these chapters have 9-14 sections each with over 100 definitions.

He's actually not terrible at lecturing. I really enjoyed the content in Systems Security. The projects cover the content well but feel a bit dated. Most assignments weren't too difficult.
Grades took unacceptably long to come in and he is lazy.
Not a great prof, but if you were interested in taking a class, I wouldn't not just because it's him.

There's no reason this man should be teaching first-years. One of the WORST professors I've ever had, and CS115 was my first college class. I am a third-year now and, looking back, he is one of the biggest reasons I have always felt incompetent as a CS major. For the love of GOD do not take him for CS115. Take Terolli or ANYONE else instead.
I think he was only good for CS 101 since it was an online class. It was still graded in a strange way. He probably wouldn't be ideal if you had him for an in-person class.
Terrible professor, the class was very boring, 2 weeks left and he still hasn't posted the syllabus. The first week he read straight from Wikipedia.

Terrible professor. He is extremely condescending, extremely unresponsive, and extremely disorganized. I emailed him four times this semester and he never responded. He changed the grading scale two weeks before class ended and never provided a syllabus. He is the king of answering questions without answering them. Do not take any of his classes!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Started with recursion day 1 when I only knew how to print. Professor had heavy accent which was tough to understand. He did not show up to office hours even after I emailed him. Scored 36% on first exam. Score was curved 20 points then rounded in a bell curve. I got a 56% with the curve and then rounded down to a ZERO! Had to drop the class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Took a 284 class. Rounded me down on my midterm and final to fit the "bell curve." Please do not take his courses.

Tests had unrelated material. Cant understand a single word coming out of his mouth. He would release the topics for the midterm/final 12 hours before the exam time. IT Security is an important class for CySec majors but nobody learned a thing from this course

(Not actually CS 334 - but CS 576 isn't listed as an option)
Disorganized, I can definitely see how the CS 115 students struggle under him.
That said, his systems security course was pretty good. Assignments and assessments felt reasonable. 
TA is clearly doing a lot of good work for the course, so your mileage may vary. Come to lecture and labs.

Do not take this professor if you have no prior CS knowledge. Nicolosi is extremely unorganized and you will need to teach yourself. He did not give a syllabus until the last week of class. His lectures are hard to understand with plenty of rambling. Awful quizzes that do not really test your knowledge of the material. Avoid him at all costs.
Very tough grader and with no prior computer science knowledge it is hard to get a good grade

Without the assignments that he gives out through the course, I do not think I would have done as well as I should have. Though, I do believe that without prior computer science knowledge, this course will genuinely be difficult. The lectures are alright, but I had a hard time understanding what was going on majority of the time.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Nicolosi is extremely unorganized. Grading structure/syllabus was not provided until right before final exam. Homework assignment due dates often changed less than an hour before due date and time. Labs were difficult for me and TA was not knowledgeable and was not able to answer questions. Be prepared to teach yourself.
Has no clue what hes teaching and makes an intro to cs class way harder than it actually has to be do not take this class with this professor if you have a choice
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: If you have no coding experience before taking this class, good luck. Lectures are useless because you most likely won't understand what he is saying. Most people end up teaching themselves using online resources and office hours. Do anything you can to switch professors.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: This class was very anxiety inducing for me. We were not given a syllabus until the last week of class, and I was constantly questioning what my grade actually was. If you study on your own, its possible to get an A in the class. He drops a lot of grades which is his version of a curve. Good luck, and remember your TAs are there to help you!

FOR CS115: Often changes due dates last second. Lectures are not very helpful, learning on your own or in groups are much easier. Probably one of the worst professors I've had so far, if you can stay away then I highly recommend that. I skipped about a month of lectures, still earned an A-, so attendance is not mandatory.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Nicolosi can be disorganized sometimes. I emailed him about doing summer research, and I'm still waiting for a response to this day. But other than that great proffessor, and fairly easy class, especially if you have some programming knowledge going in.

If you are a freshman and are assigned CS115 with this professor, reach out to your advisor about switching to someone else. You essentially have to teach yourself the class, even the TA's and tutors are fed up with it. Not only does he have an extremely heavy accent but he mumbles throughout lectures and always leaves out vital information.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Professor is very smart and knows what he is doing but has difficulty conveying ideas so that the students can understand it. With coding experience, you will find it difficult but be ok. Without programming experience you will need to put in extra time and effort. Also worth mentioning he is a very strict grader, at least for online exams.

I am a current cs115 student. He knows his craft but does not convey it at all. Will spend a whole lectures time on one subject and pop quiz you on another. Lists all the necessary study material for tests and then completely disregards it. Barely passed with extreme amount of outside of class effort.

I'm a current CS-115 student of Professor Nicolosi's and he doesn't seem interested in making sure students understand what's going on. Won't learn nearly as much as you would in the other class. Be prepared to teach yourself. Class spikes in difficulty and can go from easy to impossible from one day to the next.

I'm a current student in Nicolosi's CS-115 class. The teacher does not seem passionate with teaching; I don't believe he truly cares about what he's doing. You will not learn nearly compared to Naumann's class. CS-115 also spikes in difficulty from time to time. Labs can range in difficulty from very easy to challenging.

Nicolosi is such a bad professor but I can't knock him completely because he curves the grades hard. Percentage-wise I had a D and I ended up with I think a B. He has a thick italian accent and is pretty bad at explaining things, but that curve definitely helps!

He taught the class at a higher level than a lot of people were prepared for, leaving a lot of students lost and confused. He skipped over the basics of Python that were necessary for understanding the rest of the course. If you have him, be prepared to look for a tutor.

Nicolosi knows his material, yet he is very poor at conveying it. His lectures aren't intriguing, and it is very hard to understand his Italian accent as he speaks very fast. The labs for CS181 are not that bad if you pay attention during lecture, yet the exams (at least for my year) are just writing code that you have no experience with.

Nicolosi is a fantastic professor, as long as you ask questions. He moves fast (like people do in CS) and if you don't ask him questions, he assumes you got it. If you ask questions when you don't understand, you will do fine. He's really smart.  You will have to get over the Italian accent, though. He acknowledges this and isn't offended.
Really wants to improve both himself and students.

You can hardly understand him and when you do, its impossible to follow. He jumps around and its awful trying to figure out what he's actually trying to teach. The programming assignments are mostly irrelevant and useless. The year starts easy and then jumps to impossible out of nowhere. His tests are made for a 3 hour period but only gives 45 min

No feedback, graded on a ridiculous scale,  clearly did not care about class, errata present in problems on assignments and tests that students lost credit for. Avoid if you actually want the grade you deserve.
Great class, but for the first few days it's kind of hard to understand him with his accent. However, he's very helpful in his office hours, and the CAs are always ready and willing to help.
Easy to understand once you get over the italian accent, knows what he's doing and makes himself and CA's available.
Good. Refreshingly honest with students, especially at such a nerdy school. Participation matters a lot, and attendance is taken every class.

Really cool professor, grades papers quickly and has an interesting topic for the course. You should definitely talk in her class, participation is important, and it'll make the class far more enjoyable since she is super lively.

I would give Dr. Hammerman my kidney if she asked for it politely. She is such a wonderful and entertaining professor, and I absolutely loved taking CAL105 with her last semester. Also, her assignments are about as fun as CAL105 assignments could possibly be. Love this woman.
Very understanding professor that clearly cares about the student body, and essay topics are practicable and often flexible.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: By far the best professor I've had at Stevens so far. The class is heavily discussion/participation based, but the discussions are insightful and well worth participating in. The professor is fun and relatable, and makes the classroom a comfortable place to be for everyone. She is very understanding and accommodating, and is a pretty easy grader

Hammerman is a great professor and the class is easy. She is really funny and interactive with the class and it's honestly what you make of it. The books we read were actually interesting too, great choices by her. Go to the writing center if you want a good grade from her.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: I just don't try in class, but she keeps us interested.  It's less of a discussion and more of her explaining her thoughts, which isn't a bad thing.

Prof Hammerman curses left and right, but makes you feel at home in her class. She cares about your course load and doesn't pile on work, and was always accessible outside of class for help with essay writing or concepts. She doesn't care about phone use, and the textbook can be found online for free. Laptops are used in class.
Not too bad of a grader but the class was boring, would not suggest taking it if not mandatory.

One of the NICEST professors!!! What I liked about her is she treated us like her equals. She felt like a real person engaging in discussion with us instead of someone just spouting out information. Towards the end of the semester, we watched Bob Ross videos in class, and she even recommended me for a job on campus!

I love Professor Hammerman so much! She always asks how we are doing and really cares about our wellbeing. She is open to reading original work from students, which is honestly above and beyond my expectations, and is prompt with grading. I never had a teacher grade my full paper within an hour of its submission, equipped with several comments!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Accessible outside class--Gives good feedback

comment: Hammerman is the best professor at Stevens. She actually cares about how we are doing. If you need help writing the essays or understanding the assignments she will spend time with you during office hours. Also she is really open to different ideas and opinions so everyone is comfortable with participating in class.

She is a real gem. She asks about your course load and assigns assignments according to how the class feels about work load that week. PARTICIPATE. Cannot stress that enough. She loves students that are insightful in class discussions and values individual opinion on texts and social issues. Written assignments are doable and usually short.

Professor Hammerman will make it clear right away she's not afraid to curse left and right, and it seems a bit over the top once you're deep into the semester. She is respectful of your other classes and does not pile on too much work. Attendance is taken in each class. Laptops are allowed to be used.

Dr. Hammerman's a real colorful character. She cusses every other word, talks about other professors drinking, and grades in ranges (like B - B+ rather than just a B). Overall, she's a very charismatic teacher and if you participate, you'll probably have a lot of fun. My main complaint is her lack of feedback. I got virtually none on my essays.
Excellent professor.

Dr. Hammerman made CAL 103 a lot of fun and overall I enjoyed her class. Make sure you participate in class and you will be perfectly okay. I didn't mind the essays or group research paper, and Dr. Hammerman's lectures help a ton with understanding the literature.

Participate but don't be annoying about it. Extremely tough grader. If you ask for help, she will happily direct you to the writing center, then to herself if you still need it. Do your work and relax. Very easy going and she gives the essay topic ahead of time.

Participation is key. Also, she basically tells you what you'll need to write on the essays, just pay attention in class. She grades more easily as the class progresses so don't be pissed if you get like a c+ first grade
Passionate about her class, and a funny professor. She's not the easiest grader, but if you participate in class and ask for help she will help you get the grade you want.

She loves what she does, and it shows. She's quite the character and can be convinced to let you peer review in the dining hall or have class outside, but you do have to produce solid papers and PARTICIPATE in class discussions to get a good grade.

One of the only profs who noticed that sometimes only one person does all the work in a group projects. She was funny and we would always go off topic in class.  she helped if you asked for it, but she always took attendence
Rants for hours and bores the class, doesn't provide one on one feedback except after she's grades the essays. Her saving grace is her dark humor
Really cool teacher. Helpful.
Really cool teacher
Interesting and casual class. If she likes you the class will go well.
Decent professor. Very casual class. Decent grader. Go to class and turn in everything on time and participate.

Great professor. She makes everything interesting and class is like an open discussion which sparks some unique thinking that lead us down some pretty interesting roads, especially when talking about Byron. She's a tough grader but if you really try you will do fine and learn a lot while enjoying yourself in the process.
