Able to make everyone feel smart and welcome in the class discussions. Very relaxed class - more like a conversation with friends than a lecture.

Absolutely horrible teacher. Papers are heavily centered around philosophy and ethics. Very reading heavy. Tough grader on papers. Gives almost zero helpful feedback on papers. Unless you're capable of analyzing the philosophy behind every word in an article then DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS.

This guy left Stevens, so most of t= students won't know the spectacle they're missing. My only regret is that throughout the semester I did not write down his puns and one-liners, all memorable! The few I remember are still my best lines at parties. The guy wanted to teach us complex variable calculus - hence the generalized hate below.

The professor was very nice but didn't really do his job. He rarely uploaded things on canvas and never assigned official homework. As for exams, he made them online last second and the questions were straight from the textbook, but he either forgot to grade the exams or graded them at the end of the semester and didn't give any feedback.
He was flexible with due dates if the class spoke up but overall he was not good at communicating or teaching the material. The exams were pretty fair but the homework was very difficult to do.

Professor Sabau taught 200-level math concepts at a graduate level, which obviously overcomplicated things. He also cancelled class multiple times, and because of that we fell far behind with the material, and he blamed us for not trying to learn topics on our own time. He's gone after this semester so it won't matter much anymore.

Professor Sabau was much better than the reviews say. While it can at times move very quickly or very slowly the actual material is not incredibly difficult to do. Expect 10-15 minute long tangents about anything and everything ranging from wars in other countries to his first halloween in the US. Overall, very funny guy but a bit mid at teaching.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He's better than what I saw on the reviews.  He didn't give out any homework whatsoever but the class was fun to have.  The first half of the class was rough with the discrete, but made more sense once complex numbers came into play.  He has funny stories about Europe and could be a great history prof too lol.

MA230. awful. never graded homework, never responded to emails, never explained concepts properly. I studied for a month over the winter to prepare for the class by using the syllabus. waste of time, none of the exam topics were on the syllabus. final was online cuz we told him for 20 minutes how we learned nothing, which saved our grades.

Nice guy but not the best at explaining concepts. Class was proof heavy and tests were difficult. Don't bother buying the textbook because he doesn't use it at all. Doesn't assign much homework, so your grade is 90% made up of what you get on exams. He genuinely wants his students to do well and is approachable, teaching could be better though.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Caring

comment: Tries to explain undergraduate concepts at a graduate level. Is a very nice man but an awful professor. Also he tends to ramble and go on tangents a lot.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: The class is difficult, but the professor cares.
No No NO!!! Just a nightmare to work with.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Serban Sabau is the cult classic of professors: a vast majority of the students just don't get him. He is unintentionally one of the most entertaining professors at Stevens. His stories he tells during breaks are unmatched by any. The grades you get don't matter, only your placement compared to others determines your final grade. It was fair.
Only professor for the Fall and Spring semesters. So you have no choice but to deal with his horrificness.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: 3 of my friends and I were EE majors. After taking this course with Sabau 2 of those friend left EE and completely left the engineering school. HWs are useless to do since he they have no affect on your final grade. 50% of your grade is Midterm and 50% is Final. Fail the midterm you have drop the class and take him once again next semester.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: He's one of the laziest individuals in the world. His class is confusing and he's always trying to shirk his responsibilities.
I've had community college instructors teach way better than him. And Stevens is suppose to be one of the finest institutions for innovation yet a professor like him ruins that reputation.

Throwing oil into a fire to quench said fire is the way I'd describe Sabau's teaching skills. Why? Because he just keeps throwing material and not explaining it despite us all being confused. He only teaches by proofs with no explanations. He doesn't grade anything during the semester. Oh, and he lost our ungraded midterms 2 days before the final.

Good Luck with his class. Nice person outside the classroom but inside the classroom he's tough. No understands the grading nor understands there standing in the class until the final grades come out.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Tests? Not many--Tests are tough

comment: This professor is horrible. The homework is all based on rigorous mathematical proofs. I don't know who came up with the title "Introduction to Control Theory", but there is nothing introductory about this class or this professor. The homework and tests will be problems you can't find in the book or online, you will be confused every week. Avoid.

The class itself is always going to be difficult because the topics are difficult, but Shudong does a good job teaching and if you go to the lectures and pay attention, it isn't as bad as other people make it out to be. The homeworks and projects are difficult, but manageable.
Lots of hard stuff but its all in the textbook, gives lots of extra credit that makes up for making me learn assembly.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Shudong is a great professor. His lectures clear up any confusion you may have after reading the textbook. Yes this class is demanding, but it pays off afterwards. Office hours are key! If you ever find yourself confused about a topic discussed in class, make sure to pay a visit to the CAs. Shudong hires very knowledgeable CAs.

Great professor. Lecture optional and textbook made by him so you can learn everything out of class. only textbook i read for class, read it. Lectures are not bad but are more for understanding concepts rather than helping with performing on homeworks/exams. Lots of opportunity for extra credit, and fair exams that are very close to review material

He's a good professor with a hard course. If you pay attention in class, you should be fine. His textbook is written well, and when used as a supplement with the lectures, guarantees you a good grade in the class. The only tip for this class is start EVERYTHING early, you WILL need the extra time to get everything done.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Shudong wasn't the greatest professor in his first few years, but he's improved a lot. The concepts are very tricky, but if you read the textbook and actually go to class, you'll be fine. He's also a great person to get to know! Definitely more lenient in 392 than 382.

The exams are hard, but I absolutely love him. He's a master of reducing down topics and makes fantastic visuals. He writes his own text book (which he gives you) so he knows the content inside and out. Lots of detailed examples and demos. Homeworks are the perfect length, interesting, and on topic. Easy recommendation.

He is a nice professor but not a good exam maker. His exam focus too much on tiny details and takes away a lot of points. I took both 382 and 392, and the exam was hard asf. Based on what he said this is the third year he teach. I was told 382 exam average 2022 was 36 , 2023 was 46 or 56, so do work hard for exam

This course is extremely challenging, be prepared to read the textbook beforehand, else you are probably going to be really lost. The exams are extremely difficult, you can expect to spend a lot of time doing practice questions on your own if you wish to do well on the exams. For your reference, the course average for most exams are in the 60-70s.

He does not accept any late work no matter what. Lectures are really great and homework assignments are always interesting. In every lecture, he gives out hints on the content of midterms and final. He is very friendly and is impressed by doing hws with recursion.

If you're a CySec major, you're really going to be going through it when you take this class. On top of 334 and 385, 382 will be the most laborious. I managed to get 100s on most of the homework/labs, but I allocated more hours than I should have for this class. The grading certainly doesn't help, since 36% was the average for the first exam.

Professor Hao is a great lecturer but the course had a rough start. It had harsh grading procedures and a lack of rubrics. The first midterm had 75% of the class get below a 60, but the class turned around after the first half. He is a great lecturer and changed a lot over the semester. The class was loads of fun after he changed. High workload!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Shudong is MUCH better in 392, but it's also a better course. He gives you everything you need to do the homework assignments. They all felt fair except for std392io and midterm 2. I enjoyed him and the lectures. If you don't get a 100 on an assignment, no extra credit for it. Very knowledgeable, but still learning how to be a good professor.

He is highly unprofessional. Reading the textbook is a MUST, but it probably won't help you very much on the tests. The homework and the labs do not really relate to what we are learning in class, and honestly some of the assembly ones just feel like busy work. Do not recommend.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: He is condescending to his students and expects you to know everything by heart after saying things one time. His grading may not be too harsh but it is often wrong.

Every question on Shudong's exams are straight out of his textbook, so just pay attention and read and you'll be fine. Learned a lot in this course, and despite being quite harsh with credit on certain assignments, he is a good professor.

He's honestly an awesome professor! All you needed to do was either pay attention during lectures or watch the lecture recordings and take notes. He goes out of his way to connect with students and provide help when we ask for it. He also listens to course feedback and curves the class. You may have to email him a few times about misgraded work.

He expects you to know the material from heart and more after he is done teaching it. For labs little to nothing to do with the actual things you learn in the class. makes you write assembly code of things that would be ten times easier to code in c++, java, or python like merge sort. Class and labs does not relate to each other around the week 5.

Shudong is honestly an amazing teacher if you pay attention in lecture. I was learning a lot in the beginning, but then I stopped paying attention after a certain point and I was just so lost. Very heavy on homework and labs. Only bad thing is that grading is not consistent. There is a lot of bad grading but if you email him, he will fix it.

Has a real in-depth understanding of the course and is equipped to answer a wide arrange of questions. He's pretty unforgiving in terms of late assignments or any requests for extensions. Very available outside of class for help in terms of emails and office hours and overall shows that he cares about helping and getting to know the student.

Labs and non-written homework assignments, which is most of the work, is just barely related to the course material, and really hurts when it leaves us barely knowing what to answer on the tests. Said labs and programming assignments are a struggle for students, and due dates are so close to each other that received help is minimal.

If this guy sued me I would still respect him. It is nearly impossible to have anything against the guy. So easy to talk to if you need help or if you want to talk, friendly, engaging lectures, low work load. Clear grading criteria.
Incredible professor for this class and serves as an excellent introduction to the QF program. extremely knowledgable on the subjects he teaches, you learn a lot and low stress, just read the WSJ!

You will need to read the WSJ everyday as well as his blog where he posts articles he finds interesting, as there will be a 10 question quiz on them every class. Super easy and in fact becomes part of your routine to read the journal.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Amazing lectures

comment: Just read the WSJ. That's basically it. Free A.

Professor Calhoun is an amazing teacher that makes lectures interesting and is always willing to help his students. I took his course through the pandemic, and Calhoun always catered to his students. He always provided reasonable feedback on group presentations and taught us useful information for the future.
My favorite prof at this school. He always gives great lectures and has a lot of valuable real world knowledge. As long as you pay attention in class and take notes and read WSJ you will be fine.

Calhoun is an absolute legend. Took him last year. Most of the class is based on open-notes Wall Street Journal quizzes. No homework, just takes notes on WSJ for the quizzes. The tests are fine too (also open notes). Some presentations, but they aren't hard. Honestly, as long as you show up and sorta pay attention, you'll end up with an A/A-
Calhoun is awesome. His class is super easy if you just read the wall street journal. There's a quiz every day but they're easy.

Professor Calhoun is a great professor. You'll have to do a lot of work to get a good grade for his classes' quizzes and presentations, but all that work definitely pays off during interviews and all.

George is great. The entire grade is pretty much based off of the Wall Street Journal quizzes. Just don't do horribly on the presentations, midterm or final. His lectures are engaging and he is a very good teacher. He has a lot of valuable finance experience that he brings to the class. Best teacher at Stevens. He might be mean during presentations
great guy, interesting class

He was the best college professor I had. Super smart and humbly the most successful professor at Stevens in terms of previous  industry engagements, academia, etc. He is able to explain difficult businessfinance concepts in a very understandable way-- and give you the real-world feel -- no doubt the instrumental prof in my success at Stevens.
He is a great teacher and actually made me more interested in finance. He is also extremely helpful outside class and very responsive.
Keep up with your Wall Street Journal. Very unconventional teacher but it works
Keep up with Wall Street Journal readings and assigned novels. He responds to emails slowly. Lots of time must be dedicated to reading, as the questions are always vague.

He uses current events a lot in his class, so it is important to stay well informed.  His quizzes center around readings from the WSJ and are held on a daily basis.  He also posts additional readings on his blog.  I give him high marks all around for focusing on relevant contemporary information regarding the current business environment.

This guy is a great educator.  He will make you work hard and he knows how and when to encourage, reward, and rebuke.  At the same time, his teaching style prepares you for the real world; this is never more true than with Prof. Calhoun.

Great Professor, really understands how to teach in a modern style. It's ashame anyone gave him a poor rating, it's probably because he requires a lot out of his students and only the best receive the grades they deserve.
He was a pretty easy guy in the seminar class. Just make sure you read the wall street journal. I heard he gives a quiz everyday on that material.

very difficult to understand his speaking and writing,
bad lecture quality
you have 4 attempts for an assignment, but the final grade you get for that is not the HIGHEST but the AVERAGE. (50+90+90+100)/4>(50+100)/2. So intentionally giving some wrong answers is the best play.
No coding prerequisite but a random python project at the end of semester

One lecture to watch a week that goes over everything you need to know for the weekly homework assignment. Nothing in the class feels unfair and he gives you four options to calculate your final grade so that you can maximize your grade or skip the final which is very nice.

Lecture videos are terrible and don't match the difficulty of the homework at all. Gets a 3 bc the homework is the best resource to learn the material, and you have plenty of attempts at it. But exams are brutal, he's unforgiving with grades and points back, and not accommodating at all. Prepare A LOT for the tests, and don't expect any leeway.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He's a great professor.  Took the web section however, so I can say that some of the lectures did not align with the homework or even the test, but was useful for the most part.  Heard he's one of the better, more competent professors here in person, so I'm not docking him due to my online experience.  There is more homework, but I found it useful.

For those taking the web section of E243, the recordings are over 5 years old and are pretty trash. You can't learn from them. Try to take in-person or get recordings from those people. Have a good support network and practice to not bomb the exams and you can walk away from the course without a sweat.

He's a cool professor, even in the summer where classes are usually a lot quicker he engages the class A LOT. So pay attention in the lectures because he might call on you to offer insight on a problem. Might only be applicable to smaller summer classes. Either way, a good professor, and a good grading scheme. Not too difficult to get a good grade.

Best grading criteria in this school. You will know if you have an A or A- and what you need to do to get those letters. The first few chapters are the most difficult, but after those the course gets better. Be prepared for the first exam, it will catch you off-guard. Participate in lecture, and you will do great. Very understanding.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: He's a pretty generous grader, gives alot of points back as long as you show some proper work for it, even if you get the answer wrong. He's also super accessible & helpful outside class during his office hours. If you struggle with hw, you'll struggle on the quiz, so make sure to go to office hours if you're confused.

This is one of the hardest classes I've ever taken being is Prof. Jagupilla's class. I've taken AP statistics in high school and this was no comparison. The professor has no understanding on how to relay the material understandably to the students. Horrible professor.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: He needs to rebalance the class. The exams are difficult and he does not give a lot of credit back like he claims. He does not consider additional circumstances in the world or cut students a break, ever. Homeworks are ridiculously unforgiving and don't end up affecting your grade like they should for the amount of time and effort they demand.

Great professor. He has a real dad vibe going on, and it makes him great to be around. He truly cares for his students' success and well-being. Has a very strong command of the material and can quickly explain many of the more complex questions brought up by students. My advice: Pay attention. He's a master of calling on people who are zoning out.
Don't be fooled thinking this class is an easy. Jagupilla tests heavily on your knowledge of the subject.

This class is not stressful in the sense that there just 6 homeworks and 2 quizzes throughout the semester. But the amount of difficultly in the quizzes are not the same with the difficultly with the hw. He needs to be a bit more fair. HWs are also just 15% of your grade so getting a 100 on them does not mean you will be getting an A in the course.

Only thing hard about the class were the in-class quizzes. which are 17.5% of your grade each. So doing bad in one can lower your grade by one letter. His Final policy is dumb because if you take it you risk getting a lower grade. He should make the final replace an old quiz grade.

J is a solid choice for prob/stats. His course is structured to outline the history and derivation of formulae in lecture, then to browbeat you with their applications in recitation. It works superbly. His teaching method is a laid-back lecture style, and he engages the class when possible. Final: Optional. Homework: Your best bet at getting an A.

Very helpful professor. Reasonable grader, easy going and provides plenty of course material. I feel like i learned a great deal and the class was not a huge amount of stress thanks to his teaching style.
Very helpful, a bit difficult to understand at times, but overall an incredible professor. Really knows the material. Very open to questioning.
Teaches the class nicely, and covers all the material well. Very easy-going and helpful.

Alex is such a fun professor. I never missed one of his classes, I wish I was in the class from the very beginning. The papers were a lot and, it was kind'ave tiring. Yet, the content was so interesting. I loved this class, and would love to take another course under this professor.
Fun lecture but too much writing for a 100 level class
Amazing professor. I only had him for Pinnacle Seminar but he is so down-to-earth and well-respected. Seminar was fun.
Best professor I had this semester. Really enjoyed the class and material, and looked forward to lectures. Office hours are a huge help- take advantage of them!
This was a pass/fail seminar class, and Professor Wellerstein was amazing throughout it. He really cares about his students, and does his best to make every single class interesting.

Hes so awesome!!! His lectures are funny but not in an over the top way. For the midterm, he drew little pictures based on what I wrote and didnt mind that I got excited and wrote too much. Hes a good person. He will talk about his wife and dog a lot, and its so clear that he loves them so much. Im lucky to have got him my first semester.

Wellerstein is a really nice and funny person. He is really knowledgeable, gives great feedback, and almost always has a joke lined up somewhere in his lectures. He is one of the best humanities profs I've had at Stevens.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Hilarious

comment: HST-415 is by far my favorite class I have taken at Stevens, and I would recommend anyone to take it if it's offered! I'm not one to usually enjoy weekly readings, but each reading and recorded lecture was really interesting and had my attention the entire time. The papers in the class aren't hard, but get started on the final paper early.

I've taken several classes with Prof Wellerstein and he is easily my favorite professor at Stevens. His lectures are interesting and he's really passionate about his field and it shows. You'll have to read and write a bit, but as long as you put in some effort (no spelling mistakes, at least skim the article) you'll get a good grade.

He isn't just a great professor, he's a great human. He deeply cares about students, takes time out of class to offer insight about everything, and is insanely knowledgeable all-round. He will make you write papers, but never any busy work without meaning. Best of the best professors, and not taking him at least once honestly does you a disservice.

Great class! An easy A as long as you do the work. He's willing to give extensions and he is obviously super passionate about this course. I recommend this class to anyone looking for an easy humanity class since there are no tests and its pretty interesting.

Wellerstein is awesome. Funny and gives good feedback on research papers. He does give a lot of short papers to write but he's generally not a harsh grader. He's also super easygoing so if you're ever late on an assignment shoot him an email he most likely will say yes to an extension. He also gives A LOT of extra credit opportunities.

Wellerstein is the best professor I've had so far. He is incredibly charismatic, and there is rarely a dull moment in his classes. The only real downside to this class is the immense amount of papers. He has us write two 500 word essays a week, and thats not including the 3 or 4 larger papers we have to write over the semester.

Wellerstein is a true gem at Stevens. He is the professor you want for CAL-105. There are quite a few smaller papers in his class, but they are more or less your personal opinions on the readings. He's extremely knowledgeable in nuclear weapons and their history and effectively integrates his expertise into the class. Enjoyed every moment.

Hes the best. An expert on nukes, he developed the viral website Nukemap. If you dont take him, youre missing out. Every moment of his class is exciting and I wouldnt miss a minute. He even gave us a twenty dollar video game for free for educational purposes

Wellerstein is easily the best professor I've had at this school. Unironically teaches coding better than anyone I've had in CS, and his lectures hold my attention despite having a serious attention problem otherwise. Assignments are challenging, but he makes sure you have all the tools to succeed, and if you put in a good effort he'll reward it.

Honestly one of the best professors I've ever had. Nuclear Era is his forte, he's so passionate and makes everyone love it too. I look forward to his class and wouldn't mind if it was a 10 hour lecture.

My favorite professor. He's incredibly personable, interesting, and makes classes fun. He's very accommodating and wants to help you succeed in assignments. Aside from straight up teaching, he incorporates discussion into every lecture and class participation is a big part of your grade.

Prof Mullan is very sweet. Her lectures are boring but if you stay engaged she makes some funny remarks. She's very clear with her grading criteria; so long as you follow her requirements, you will get at least a 93 on every assignment. Meeting with her for office hours will also help secure an A. Talks a lot (can get off topic), but very funny
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Was boring and monotonous, very easy to get bored in class. Tests were open-note so that was nice. Overall on essays, everyone would get the same grade for the most part, so she isn't a super tough grader, but it is hard to get above a 95 on an essay with her. The texts she chose were interesting but unfortunately not presented well.

Don't take a class with Prof Mullan. Her lectures will put you to sleep and your grade won't reflect your work. She'll give back papers and tell you to see her after class to translate her hieroglyphics. If she sees you're not passionate for her class she'll you suggest to drop. If you have an option to another professor/elective. Take it.

This professor will put you to sleep no matter what class you take of hers. She almost never gives above a 90 on any paper. She hates any information that she didn't say in class. If you're looking to learn something interesting, avoid at all costs. Not hard to get an A, but you gotta memorize the study guides. If you have other options, take those
such a sweetheart!! idk why she has so many negative reviews because personally I thought she was a pleasure to have as a professor. Would definitely take her again
Don't do this to yourself. Any other CAL105 class will be better and less painless. She only has 5 assignments and gives all students the same grades on the essays.

Overall she is a very misunderstood Professor. Yes, there may be only 5 grades for the class but the final and midterm are very straightforward if you follow the study guide she provides. The 3 essays are not difficult as long as you take enough time to prepare. Lectures may have been a bit boring at times but overall a good Professor
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: The reviews below me are 100% accurate on what happened in her class. Lectures are super boring and involve very little discussion. She only cares about the midterm and final more even though the essays require a lot more time and effort. Everyone gets similar grades on the essays so those almost always hold your grade back
Our whole class hated her. Such an inadequate professor.

BAWARE!!! Your final grade is only comprised of 5 assignments. She gives all students basically the exact same grade on all essays, so the only thing that matters are the in-person memorized multiple-choice midterm and final. Not to mention, most CAL105 courses don't have a midterm/final and if they do, they are a peer review/reflection/online. RUN

Do not take! Avoid at all costs. She is beyond boring. I'm sure she is very knowledgeable and passionate about philosophy and teaching but she really needs to retire. She is not very tech savvy and doesn't know how to captivate the class. She literally just reads the notes from her powerpoint. Most of the students feel the same in the my class.

Class may not be the most interesting if you aren't into philosophy, but Prof. Mullan is a solid choice for CAL. Essays and tests were straightforward and as long you pay attention in class you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Skip class? You won't pass.--Gives good feedback

comment: Do not take her class! never trust her smile she seems kind in class but you may be surprised by her grading. I do not advise anyone to take her class. You get boring lectures which no cares. I will avoid her class at all costs. This class made me hate the whole college experience. Do yourself a favor and take this class with a different prof.!!!
NOT AN EASY A!! The midterm and final were super tough. The essays were easy.

Really boring lectures. Hard not to fall asleep. But she's passionate about the subject and if you participate and you are wrong it doesn't matter. She really does appreciate the effort. Just so up to class answer a question or two and you are set.

I loved having Professor Mullan. A lot of people say that her class is boring, but she is very passionate about what she teaches if you listen. She offers extra credit for attending extra lectures and is an easy grader.  Very easy to get an A in this course. I would definitely take this class again. She is a wonderful, kind person.
Very easy but strict about phones and sleeping
knows her stuff, very kind and helpful. lectures were very dull and tended to drag on. incredibly easy grader

Great man, super funny dry humor. Very willing to help in understanding of the material. Records all lectures and curves the homework and sometimes tests. Very fair, but medium-difficult material. Would take any class he teaches.

MA232 is slightly easier than MA121-126. It's clear how much he cares about students and ensuring everyone is able to do well. His lectures are great and he records/posts all of them. Grade is entirely composed of weekly homework (~3hrs to do) and exams. Also very helpful and accomodating.

The multiple choice on the tests are the hardest part of the class. His lectures are straightforward and he livens up the class with cat videos. Lectures are still a bit dull, but he does his best to make sure students are learning.

He makes this class easier than I thought it would be.  He gives problem sessions every week and he checks with most kids to see how they're doing.  He also analogizes linalg to cat videos on reddit, so his meta is cool.  Good luck on multiple choice, but the rest of the class is fairly similar to the test.  Meow or purr or something.
The professor is hard to follow during lectures. The organization of the course material is good. However, the lectures are not engaging and idk if he's happy to teach them.

Nikolaev is one of, if not the best math professor at Stevens. His grading schemes are incredibly lenient, he shows funny cat videos in class for a little break from lecturing, and has a dry sense of humor that I find hysterical. While the material may be difficult for some, he explains everything super clearly, and is willing to help.

Nikolaev clearly cares about the lectures and his students. He is good at teaching and goes at a good speed. You do need to participate though. He expects answers in the PollEVs. He's also hilarious, making a "stop the count" joke during class once. His voice can be hard to understand at times. Enthusiastic about math and enjoys teaching it.

The lectures are monotonous and Nikolaev is a very harsh grader. The material could be more frequently tied to CS and stats rather than just boxes of numbers. I would take another one of his classes because he explains things well, but boring. Zero effort was put into the exams, typos in more than one, you'd think they'd at least look it over.

He's a nice guy but I felt there was too much material to cover in only 2 lectures/week, so the lectures are a bit rushed. HWs are like 40% of grade and they're graded, but they'll be similar problems to ones in class. On tests the first 1/3 of it were ridiculously hard multiple-choice qs that pretty much everyone guessed on, hence bad test grades

Very accommodating professor, but lectures were hard to follow unless you already know the material beforehand. Textbook was never directly used, but lectures closely followed the corresponding chapters. Study before each class!

Prof Nikolaev is a great guy. Definitely a harsh grader but cares a lot about the students. Be prepared to make sure your work is near perfection or else you will end up resubmitting a bunch of homework at the end of the semester. Overall, I enjoyed the class but hated pre-class exercises.
nikolaev was super harsh on grading and i could not understand anything at all. he graded assignments harshly and i practically had to withdraw bc it was too hard. AVOID!!!!!!!

The course itself is difficult, but the professor is great at explaining concepts. His teaching style is very straightforward and clear. However, he isn't super accessible outside of class, so getting help from a tutor or your TA might be a good option.

Andrey's lectures are sometimes hard to follow, but once you get the hang of it, it kind of makes sense. Make sure you attend recitations and get friendly with your TA, they are your key to success. Overall, Andrey will help you especially with graderius assignments.
Professor Nikolaev teaches the material clearly and tries to cover interesting topics. The homework follows directly from the lecture material and prepares you for the exams.

It's a tough course, but it doable if you listen to all the video lectures, take notes and read the book as you do the homework. The answers are in the back of the book so you can usually reason out the solution, which helps you learn the material. Tests are multiple choice except for the final but homework counts heavily towards your grade.
Professor is very organized and explains concepts coherently. Throws in jokes here and there. Participation in class is graded.

Nikolaev is a great professor. He explains new concepts thoroughly during his lectures and spends time answering all of our questions. He uses polls to track participation and gauge understanding, so make sure you attend lectures. He clearly loves what he's doing--he gets excited while explaining new concepts sometimes & makes math jokes often!

I took Nikolaev's class online, so the class may have been different otherwise. However, it was a good class! He uses a whiteboard to teach online, which definitely made the class engaging. He occasionally cracks jokes too. You should also participate in his class; if you don't answer poll questions, you won't get a good participation grade.
Yi Li, Me Gusta, Porque, Yi Li
she only does examples which is not very helpful to actually understand what's going on. she's a very sweet woman but you're better off going to another section

Adequate lecturer; her notes are actually pretty effective as long as you re-read them and (sometimes) read/practice from the textbook too. Sometimes it felt like she covered material slower than the other professors, so expect to study a bit harder than the other sections come test time. Also expect to feel behind, but recitations do help.
Impossible to listen to and does not know the material or teach it in an understandable way
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Genuinely cares,helps, and wants you to do well. She deserves more credit than she gets.
I agree with the guy who said she was hot

Professor Li is clearly very intelligent and would do very well in a research environment. However, when it comes to conveying that information to a class, she struggles to go beyond what's covered in her notes and explains herself by reiterating what's already been said.

Prof. Li is knowledgeable in the subject and will help you if you ask her questions and make your best effort to understand the material. However, she is quiet during lectures and could be hard to understand. Not the best prof for 221, but she does her job decent enough and conveys all the necessary information to do well on exams.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She's pretty hot ngl

Yi Li is knowledgable about differential equations, but she cannot teach. No one attends her lectures because they hurt more than just watching YouTube videos or learning it by yourself. She doesn't explain what she's doing during her lectures.

yi li's lectures are like watching a youtube video. it makes me dissociate. especially at 8 am. not a hard class but taught in such a difficult to understand way that I stopped attending her lectures and went to a different section.
Her teaching methods do not help with understanding such complicated material
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Yi Li is my favorite professor I've had here at stevens. Shes so attractive in everything she does and is significantly proficient at helping students comprehend material. I spent many 1 on 1 sessions with her and I felt amazing after every one! She makes you feel good and comfortable with the course. Fantastic professor.
Phenomenal professor, always there when you need her in every way. Great at getting information to students and her lectures were outstanding!

Her lectures are very difficult to understand, and most of the time is spent deriving the needed expressions and equations in a way that made everything seem much more complicated. Almost no time was spent in the lectures I attended addressing any questions from students. Recitation and homework was the only way I learned in this class.

So for one topic we actually covered it in recitation first and then had lecture. Leaving recitation I think I understood it but going to Yi Li's class made me lose my understanding. 0 stars but it was a good time to play some Pokemon Showdown in lecture. Hilarious prof. tho.

Not very good at communicating material to the class, which you'll isn't even that complicated once you go to the sigep reivew. Less than half the class shows up to lectures since nobody has any idea what she is teaching us during them.

Does not understand how to prioritize information. She will write about 6 white boards full of equations and tell you its all a proof, then do one example problem without explaining how it works... just assuming that the students are understanding whats going on from the 35 minute proof. Impossible to follow.

Prof. Li knows her stuff, but isn't very good at communicating her ideas. Take notes and try to understand the concept being taught or ask someone who took the course. Make sure to go to the Sig-Ep reviews! I would recommend Brady for this course because he can communicate his thoughts clearly and can explain everything in simple terms.
Extremely hard to understand.  Very fast writer, and spends several seconds asking "any questions" while continuing to face the board. Didn't learn a thing from her, read the book.

Pretty good professor if you pay attention; also very nice.  She was not the "main" professor (i.e., she did not design the tests or homeworks herself) but nonetheless, she wasn't too bad of a teacher.  I aced every test and the course as a whole, though I'm already good at math, and had an awesome TA.

Dr. Li gave a lot of homework in this class, but it was very reflective of what she talked about in lectures, so naturally, you're prepared for it. It also helps that she makes it about 60% of your grade! Because of this, I didn't feel that there were questions on exams that came out of nowhere. Very good teacher-I highly recommend!
Good teacher

MA 125/126. He goes very fast, has an accent that takes some getting used to, and overall isn't a spectacular teacher. He's not terrible, though, and he covers the material comprehensively enough and does ask the class if they understand every once in a while. If you can keep up with him and are ok with some learning by yourself then he's fine.

There's a clear grading criterion, which was very much homework and test-based grades. Attendance does matter. He does go fast regarding lectures, but he is very helpful with if you have questions or need clarification of the topic.

I took him for MA125/126. He does have an accent but you can pretty clearly understand what he's saying. He goes quite fast in his lectures and is not very great at directly explaining things. His lectures tend to be very convoluted and I found it lacks a lot of conceptual teaching which can make it difficult to learn. Good person, average prof.

Generally a good professor, but does go fast. Pay attention to the lecture material, as the slides do not cover everything. The material builds throughout the semester, so if you get lost you're in for a rough time. Good at lecturing and asks if we have questions.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: I had him for CS 503. He can go fast sometimes, but he always stops to ask if you have any questions. He sets clear grading criteria, removing the stress from all the assignments and giving good problems for extra credit. I'm not a math person, but I liked this class and would take another class with him. As long as you work, you'll be fine.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: There was a homework for every lecture which became quite excessive at times, but the tests were extremely predictable and not difficult.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Straight up the class was too easy and the midterm was a free grade >>100%. I learned a lot (that is, it was easy but not because of a lack of teaching) but I couldn't help but think during the semester that his methodology of grading was intentional. >94% for an A was fishy from the start. The slides/textbook are useful/well-made, and he's nice.
Great lecturer, great slides, great professor. I look forward to taking CS503 with him

His accent made it hard to follow along in the beginning of MA123, but after some time you get used to it. He goes kind of fast in his lectures, but does enough practice problems for you to get the general idea. Overall, not a bad Professor.

Has an accent but still easy to understand. The lecture notes are really solid and the TAs going over the material really reinforces the subject. There are supplement notes that go along with his lectures that you can familiarize yourself with the subject if you want. The midterm and final have reasonable questions that you have seen before.
Very heavy accent, often late, his lectures are so convoluted. I basically had to teach everything myself.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Graded by few things--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He's a good lecturer and has the best lecture notes in the business. Make sure to get your hands on them. Class can be hard but he's fairly accessible outside class if you reach out to him. Pretty funny too.
One of my better professors freshman year
He has a heavy accent but he's pretty energetic and he genuinely tries his best. Better than the other calc 1 profs.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: If you ask a question, he'll briefly stare at the room and try to translate it to Russian, and then answer a completely different question, but it's okay bc he's got this adorable Russian accent and arms that make you want to give him a bear hug.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I love him so much. Every day he comes in with a tight black t-shirt & jeans, sometimes a turtleneck but he quickly takes that off to reveal his luscious body. His face looks like an evil 10 yr-old, tho. He says nyem neh instead of um & gets really flustered & embarrassed if he has to think on the spot. He also plays cs-go. He's a cartoon character

He shows up exactly on time, starts writing on the board immediately, talks at us for an hour, and then leaves exactly on time.   It's difficult to learn much from his lectures. Most of what I learned was from recitation and studying with peers.

I loved Ushakov's class. His accent isn't bad. His lectures are clear, he writes clearly on the board, and explains everything very well. And quickly. If you ask a question, he'll answer. And you could see him for gaining partial credits on exams. He's also super muscly. I would love to take another class with him. He's great.
Terrible teacher. She knew nothing and pretended she knew.

Professor Wang was a really accommodating and kind professor, especially given the added difficulties of school during the pandemic. Work load was fairly light, and she covered the course material in pretty explicit detail in the lectures, making it easy to understand. Would recommend.

I had her fully online due to the pandemic and she was fine. Accommodating for students in different time zones. There were very few of each type of assignment (1-5 per category) so each assignment counted a lot towards our grade. She gives a lot of examples in slides but the subject was a little boring. Inconsistent grading by the TAs.

This course is about "pretend" course, she pretends to teach, pretends to give you feedback, and pretends to help you. However, with whole semester, she doesn't have a goal for this course, you wouldn't learn something real for this course, she makes you do many no sense presentations. She can't prove she is helpful to students

The course content is very shallow, doesn't fit to be a grad level course. Definitely not a good teacher. You can better learn from online resources. She hardly taught the subject for 5 classes. Remaining classes were Student Paper Presentations. Does not provide feedback for reducing marks, never responds to emails. Such a waster of time & money.

Completely unprofessional. Never answers to emails or canvas discussions. Doesn't communicate about her grading policy. Never shared solution sets for midterms and assignments even after asking repeatedly. Doesn't provide reasoning for deducting marks. Haven't met a professor so unprofessional & distant in my academic life.

NEVER TAKE ANY OF HER COURSES PERIOD. ABSOLUTELY UNREASONABLE GRADER AND TEACHER. Totally ruined my GPA. Doesn't provide solution sets for exams. Says the reason that she isn't providing solution sets is because the maths exam had "SUBJECTIVE" answers. I would advise anyone from ever taking any of her courses.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: smart and willing to help but is absolutely terrible at teaching. Horrible class, It's a joke.
She is very knowledgeable and loves her subject. She explains concepts well but she can be slow to answer emails.

Teaches from slides, very unclear in explanations.  Throws "pop quizzes" almost every class and grades attendance, both tactics that show her inability to keep our attention (not becuase of disinterest but of her terrible explanations). Best to just learn from slides. Avoid if you can
She can not explain things clearly, it is better to learn the slides by yourself. A knowledgeable person but not a good teacher.
She knows the material, but her slides are riddled with logical errors and she doesnt know how to get the point across. fortunately I already knew most of the material going into the class.
She is one of those professor that is really knowledgeable but cannot teach
She is willing to help but not a good teacher
Unclear when teaching, but is willing to help
WENDY IS THE BEST. SHE'S EXTREMELY NICE AND TRIES VERY HARD AND HELPS US AS BEST SHE CAN.
Horrible!

Amazing professor. Every single assignment was pretty straightforward and reasonable. If you see him teach 151 or 152, take it with no hesitation. He is very passionate about the subjects, and loves seeing his students enjoy the topics. Very memorable class.

The structure of the course notwithstanding, Dr. Lukic is a good, not great professor. Accessible, highly personalized grading (for better and for worse) and a passion for physics that only sometimes shows when teaching. Overall would recommend the scholars section to people who have a strong physics background or are OK with getting a B.
One of the most fun professors I have ever had, I really recommend taking any astronomy course with him. He makes everything he teaches you fun because he has a lot of passion for the subject matter.

Might be one of the greatest physics professors ever, but I don't know, I haven't taken many. Point is, he's great, has clear grading criteria, gives plenty of extra credit, and is able to make up problems on the spot. He is very humble and will answer questions, and it also helps that he has a very good understanding of classical mechanics.
Records all of his lectures. Tough getting used to, but it clicks eventually. As for Lukic, he is the GOAT. The man, the myth, the legend. Top Tier prof. Definitely worth taking scholars pep.

Professor Lukic is incredible. I sucked at physics entering this class, but Lukic's passion for physics and astronomy made me become more interested in physics. His problems are difficult but I guarantee class with him will be a worthwhile experience.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: I knew nothing about physics coming into this class, and I really struggled since my peers all had background knowledge from high school. But Vlad teaches the course really well, and explains a lot which really helped me.

Lukic is such a sweet guy! He cares about his class alot. However if you are someone who needs clear-cut notes to understand a new subject, he's not the guy for you. He speaks at you and lectures well, however I often found myself missing the things he just said since he didn't have notes. He just jotted on the board. But nice and great extra help.
Vlad was the coolest guy in my school. He knows how to make physics fun. He might make the occasional mistake, but everybody does that.
Passionate about teaching, not very good at it though.
So hard to pay attention in class. I feel like I've learned nothing in this class. Quizzes are very tough: class average is a 715. Heard that there's a major curve at the end of the semester.
Uncle Vlad is awesome, he's helpful and knows his stuff.  The class is hard and there was some disconnect between him and the TAs when I took it, but otherwise great.
Interesting class. Great professor. Highly recommended.

Lukic is the man. He doesn't need notes to teach, he knows his stuff that well. The class I took - Intro to Astronomy - was very well-taught. I look forward to PEP 336 (Astrophysics & Cosmology) with him next semester.
Really difficult class. No curve. That said, its pretty interesting and professor lukic is one of the most intelligent people I've met at stevens.
I love him, I didn't do well, but he's a likable professor
He knows what he's talking about and never seems bothered when students ask him for help.

The course material he teaches is clear and straightforward, which is beneficial for understanding the subject. However, he lacks the personal connection and support that students often seek. While the content is accessible, his character and approachability leave much to be desired.

Very hands off - in a bad way. He is not informed on his student's projects and seems to forget a lot of things (after all, you only meet for like ~10 minutes every 2 weeks) and just wants you to breeze through the deliverables. Provided almost no guidance.
I've never even seen him on campus.

For Senior Design you mostly just meet with your client but every couple weeks you have to meet with Klappholz. You spend 15 minutes telling him what you are doing, he either gives no advice or useless advice, and then you go do your own thing with the client again. Update: He did not even show up to the expo at the end of the year

one of the worse professor of Stevens and worst professor I ever came across, not at all accessible not sure if he's a person or bot. worst TA named Sophia, she gives marks randomly and deducts different marks for different people with same mistake. she never responds to any mails. incompetent teacher with incompetent TA. As a teacher he's unfit

This is an online class with only recorded hard to understand material and no interaction or discussion with the students. This is the worst course I have ever taken and I recommend avoiding all of his classes.

had him 20 years ago, and i still remember- first lecture, the first words out of his mouth were 'none of you will get an A in this class'. idk if he realized that statement says more about his teaching skills than the students capabilities. very rude man and miserable as a person and prof. i was glad to not have to have him for another class.
Very useful course if you want to jump into Business Analyst or Designing area.
Lectures with wrong information, doesnt listen to students, doesnt check his email, completely misunderstands the software development process.  awful professor, avoid at all costs
Doesn't listen to his students.

Very nice guy. Lectures can be a bit boring, but the information is very useful. Problem is, no one pays attention to him and then criticizes the class as being useless. If you do the work, you will be fine.

Not a very good teacher.  He is an easy-ish grader but he tends to be really sedate during lectures, extremely boring.  Wouldn't take him again.  I did end up learning a bunch during his class because it was just one big long project where we designed an entire system from scratch, in that regard it was a good class.
It was really hard to tell if he was even alive. Avoid this guy.
Somewhat boring but a nice guy.

Klappolz puts lecture notes up for each week that  pertain to our lesson which comes right out of the text book.  There are no class discussions or interaction with other students.  He takes at least a week to reply to questions that are  posted in the discussion board and his replies are quite vague.  If I wanted to learn from a text book, I cou

Stay away! He is not responsive and lectures have errors. He takes forever to grade exams and I don't think he even looks at homework submissions. He should be replaced with an adjunct, someone who knows what database professionals actually do in real life. Horrid.
Teaching Database class, He is mad, he doesn't even listen to you if you have any problem. believe me no one wants to take a course with him. He Sucks.
He also teachers CS 442. Oh my god he was the worst teacher I ever had. He only likes things exactly the way he can think of them, and is always unprepared for class. The humanity!!!!
She is AWESOME! Easy to understand and cares about her students learning. I am so disappointed to know that Professor Monika is not working in Stevens anymore. Stevens lost a real gem.
Caring and always accessible
Had amazing experience and was super helpful
Monika was a great teacher, she communicated lectures exceptionally. Big stickler with phones and paying attention in class.

overall the class went good but I recommend her to allow students use phone (sometimes). I am very shy person but when she walk around the class I get time to ask doubts. Do that more regularly. And ask students to write review. I am going to encourage my group to write their thoughts
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Get ready to work

I was in MA 225. Professor Monika is very good at teaching, her explanations are easy to understand and her lectures are well organized. Definitely attend the lectures though. She gives extra credit questions on the test. I highly recommend Dr Monika. Test problems are similar to recitation problems. Nice, caring, accessible and smart teacher.
Work hard and ask for help whenever you need. Best Professor.
Very sweet and accessible. If in doubt (any topic) reach out to her. Very knowledgable and caring. Lectures follow class pace but she never miss to answer your doubts or give time outside class

Monika was a nice lady, but she had a thick accent that made it very hard to understand what she was saying. She also did all of her lectured on her iPad and it was very difficult to keep up with her pace, and she also wasn't very organized at times. She made certain subject more difficult than they needed to be.

she's very knowledgeable, but she explains concepts at such a high level that it's difficult for us to understand. tests are much harder than problems in class. Monika is a nice, caring person, but as a prof, her lectures are unclear. study hard & prepare to reteach yourself a lot. was also overly strict ab attendance & phone usage in class
Very confusing lectures where concepts weren't explained well. Went to Taam for the second half of the semester and my mental health increased tenfold now that I understood what was going on.
Not as good as other professors

She only wrote things down on her IPad and projected it onto her screen. She would fly through the lectures and left many students confused. When it came to the tests the problems discussed in the recitation / lectures would be more advanced. To reflect on her teaching the administration had to curve everyone's grade so they would pass.
Loved the lectures and accessibility of notes videos and outside office hours too. Simply amazing. But you need to put hard work to get grades

Monika really tried to teach but just explained things at such a high level that they were impossible to understand. Lectures for the whole time and writes things down, not much else. She does give practice qs though, so go to class, do practice qs, then learn all the material yourself. All profs in this course overcomplicate things so no choice.

Speeds through lectures and leaves 2/3 of students confused. Had to reteach myself almost every lesson after class.  A decent person outside of class but a god-awful professor. She was the only option for MA117 so good luck.

A lot of people complain he is a bit quiet during class, which I get and all, but if you sit in front and go to office hours you realize he actually is an amazing professor and wants you to learn and do well. He'll take a piece of paper out and explain step by step. People need to give this man way more credit!

He is literally the quietest man I've ever met. He shouldn't have been a professor, students can't even hear him from the front row. When he is audible, he speaks complicated nonsense that just confuses people. That must be his specialty considering how ridiculously vexing his powerpoints are. Altogether, I hope Stevens realizes how awful he is.

He is literally the quietest man I've ever met. He should not have been a professor, students can't even hear him from the front row. When he is audible, he speaks over-complicated nonsense that just confuses people. That seems to be his specialty considering how ridiculously vexing his powerpoints are. Altogether, I hope Stevens how awful he is.

He lectured using slides which he gave us copies of, and it was mainly theory. I wish he gave us more in class examples or problems. He was very helpful and nice every time I went to him with questions.
He is a nice guy and is very generous when grading the recitation quizzes but he talks so low especially in Chem lab when trying to explain experiments. Moves way too quickly and hard to understand.

Great teacher, always willing to help, gives out great notes.  Tests are hard to get used to, but if you go to him for help and do your homework you'll have no trouble with the class.  As for his accent, if you pay attention it's simple to understand him.  By far the best chem eng professor.
Recitation quizes were great.  Usually getting absolutely nothing correct will give you an 8/10.

Wow, I love this guy. I love going to recitation because he makes everything much more understandable. The accent never bothered me and I think he's ridiculuously thorough. He's an amazing teacher and as long as you pay attention and remember what he says, you'll do fine.
Good professor, a little hard to understand, but he knows what he is talking about and will give you respect if you give it to him.
He just needs to learn english a bit better

I had Zhao for Chem Lab and recitation. He didn't really do much in lab besides explain it. I'm really glad I had him for recitation though. His accent is a little difficult to pick up, but after a few classes I had no problem with it. The big plus were his weekly quizzes because you were pretty much guaranteed a 6/10 for just showing up to recitat

It's three months into the semester, and I'm just decoding the accent. It still takes me about half a second to decipher any word. But as head of the lab, he's basically harmless as long as the TA for your section is cool. Keep your goggles on at all times, even during quizzes. You never know when a question will fly out and hit you in the eye.

WHAT DID HE FREAKIN SAY?!?!?!?!  He has the lowest tone possible. My first recitation was spent not learning anything, but just trying to figure out what he said. He seems like he knows a lot about chemistry, but that doesn't automatically make you a great teacher.   If you have recitation with him, try to get Sharma because at least she's clear enough to not miss a thing.
Accent is a bit thick, but his quizzes are fair and he seems to have a really good grasp on the subject.
No Comments

I had no idea what he said at all during the recitation and lab because of his accent.  For example, "arfa" means "alpha" and "perpendular" means "perpendicular".  If you get him, sit on the left side of class facing the board, it's the only side he "teaches" to and learn chinese.
An awesome awesome Chinese professor. He has a little bit of an accent but he knows his chemistry! He is very animated and thorough, and will definitely show you what's up.

stopped going to lecture 1 week in. most useless prof ever. good luck learning this material i suggest looking at pastore's notes and recitation problems before exams. exams are NEVER like the previous semester exams, so dont bother.

Whittaker isn't really a great professor but he tries to make the subject interesting and is very nice and willing to help. The class was easy you don't have to show up to pass. Just keep up with the homework every week and you'll be fine.

Was often completely incorrect in his lectures about basic physics, and would proceed to get whiny when students would not pay attention. If you want the respect of your students, you should actually have an understanding of the material you are teaching.

In smaller classes like this one, Whittaker isn't all that bad. His instructions are unclear sometimes, but he's certainly knowledgeable. Since this class is exclusively for physics majors, I feel that maybe he teaches more fluidly among his own kind.

When I wasn't sure if I could pass the class and asked what he thought I should do, he literally told me that he can't predict the future, and to figure it out myself. I've never been more furious for something school related in my life. Completely unhelpful; he didn't even try
Whittaker's a great guy! He's improved a lot over the years, apparently, because I think he's a good teacher.
I learned know little physics and passed this class. It was very easy. Just show up for clickers, do ok on quizzes and get 100 percent of mastering physics and the class is a breeze.

He does nothing.  The only day you need to go in is a clicker day.  Then, he assigns master physics.  If you do all you master physics then you pass and you don't need to take the final.  It's a joke class and a joke teacher.

Ok so he's a little lame with all of his lectures and sometimes they can get kind of boring but give the guy a break. He just really enjoys Physics. He is nice and very clear if you pay attention. Plus the class is very easy and most people get exempted from the final.

PEP 111. Mechanics. Typical Stevens professor with a superiority complex. Class is a bit of a joke though. Only need to show up on "Clicker" days and only need to show up to about half of them to get full credit. Same goes for recitations. Also, he has a habit of changing the grading system or not giving you a rubric until the last week of class.

Whittaker is the man. He is not the best teacher I have had, but he makes up for it in his personality and willingness to help. His demonstrations, while seemingly pointless at the time, have actually helped me get through the course. I so have an old man crush on him.
Honestly, terrible. Not informative, not helpful, very dry. I asked him a question on some homework i had worked ahead on, his reply was "why did you work ahead? are you cheating?"
Terrible lecturer, just plays with his physics toys.

Homework and quizzes in this class are super easy.  All of the subject material can be learned without his help,  but his lectures are always informative.  He's also a really nice guy, and funny...sometimes.
No Comments
very helpful, and nice.  always willing to help you out.
Maybe a little bit dry at points, but a very fair and thorough guy. The class is pretty easy as far as homework and quizzes go. His lectures seem a bit redundant sometimes.
horrible worst teacher ever

Professor Zabarankin is great. His class was definitely straightforward with quite a bit of homework assignments but it was nothing you cant handle. His tests were identical to the reviews and the homeworks had some challenging problems here and there. Overall, the course was pretty easy and he cares a lot about his students.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: "Dr." Zabarankin will make you forget everything you have learned about calculus. He flies through material and does not answer questions. His accent is hard to understand, especially when he tries to tell jokes in the middle of doing a problem. His tests are nothing like anything covered in class. The final is so hard.

Great course, very smart man. Everything is clear on the syllabus and it makes it easy to organize and get ahead. Tests and the final count for most of your grade so prepare well because Professor Zabarankin likes to "throw curveballs" or put hard/unexpected problems on the tests. Pay attention in class!!! He will help you if you need it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--TEST HEAVY

comment: Prof. Zabarankin is awesome! He is a math genius! It is definitely worth taking his class!
Terrible accent, speeds through material, does not understand when class is confused. Not good at explaining in a different way than his complex way of solving problems.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Took his Calc class, thought he was a great teacher. Very enthusiastic and funny. He cares a lot for the class as a whole, and will help you if needed.
Best professor I had so far.

He is very enthusiastic about his subject which is great. He makes difficult material manageable. Although his tests are not easy there will not be any surprises. If you study diligently you will do fine. He did not curve tests in my class.
If you truly want to learn, take his class!

His accent is very distracting and makes it hard to focus. He speeds through the material and always assumes everyone understands what he is teaching. His teaching style is unorganized and the material is never explained well. Don't take a class with him!

Extreme language barrier made the class difficult to understand.  He complicates the subject to the fullest extent and then questions when the students do not get it.  The test prep usually helped until it came to the final exam, which was extremely challenging.
Just okay, heavy accent, and jumped all over the place when he taught. the class was okay until the final. final was extremely hard and different than the rest of the tests

You can tell he tries so hard to get his students to understand the material, but the language barrier is still a bit of a problem. However, he's still super nice and will often curve tests and exams :)

I don't know about all these two reviews, but I can say, that his class was the worst I have taken  among 12 classes in Stevens.He loves to make the subject hard,  you cannot solve anything in the exam and then you get an A..amazing
No Comments

Zabarankin is the man. He is a good teacher, and though at first encounter he seems stern, he does, in fact, have an amazing sense of humor. He helped a lot, and I finally understood what I was doing after taking his class.
enthusiastic  very nice test reviews  but subject is still hard.

Professor Aronson is really nice and his class is not too difficult. The concepts he teaches will be useful in other classes and he uses real world examples. Make sure you study for the midterm and final because they make up the majority of your grade.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: This professor is really great for management! He cares about how you do and there are a lot of presentations, but he is a really generous grader and they're not bad at all. The midterm and final were easy. He is a little bit monotone when lecturing, but he's still a great professor!

He's nice and means well but his demeanor is just strange. He'll walk up behind you randomly and stare at your computer screen for a while which makes it a little uncomfortable. At the end of each class he'll put up a case and questions about the case and every group has to do them and present one answer (annoying but whatever). A lot of busy work

Overall Professor Aronson is super nice and really cares about the well being of the students. His lectures could be boring sometimes but the class was always split in half between lecture and group work. His class is mainly graded off of group work, but if your group works well together the class is an easy A.
Very group project heavy class but great professor

Such a nice professor and doesnt assign much work at all. Makes the class fun with talking about real life examples. Just beware that the midterm and final counts for pretty much your entire grade so you have to do good on those to get a good grade
Had him for an online class. Mostly had to read the powerpoints and participate within your group. Just contribute and youll be fine.

I took Leader Development under him. He is easily the most humble and caring professors around. Very light and enjoyable lectures. Makes you participate and makes sure he knows every single individual in class. Gives amazing feedback. 2 papers/reports(not exams), 1 mid term & 1 final and class participation. That's it, do it on time and get an A.
He really does care about his students and lecture material. Pretty easy class besides 2 papers, but made class very interesting.
Excellent Professor
Excellent Professor and outstanding material

He's one of the greatest teachers in Stevens. His direction and advice are always crystal clear and he has the most understanding on every student. The lecture is extremely helpful related to the reality out there. Overall, the best teacher for the valuable course!!
Second time having aronson as a professor. He is the easiest grader, just do the work and you will get an A. On top of that you actually learn something opposed to other professors.

Prof Zvi is one of the best professors i have had till date. He is very realistic and helpful especially in terms of flexibility of assignments and their submission dates. Extremely knowledgeable on his subject. If you do a pretty decent job, you should have no problem getting an A.
i have taken mgt680 with him back in 2002 but i still remember it was a good course, easy to get good grade
great course and very easy. Prof. Aronson is one of the nicest guys out there
No comment
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: This teacher talks to hear the sound of her own voice, rather than providing useful information. She is condescending and rude towards her students.
The worst!!
The feedback on assignments was limited, making it difficult to know where I could improve.

As someone with expertise in software development, I have noticed that Lu often relies on textbook definitions and seems to lack a deeper understanding of the practical aspects of software engineering. More hands on approach to teaching this subject would greatly benefit students.

Questions from students were frequently met with vague responses or, in some cases, she appeared unsure of the answers herself. This inconsistency in her teaching approach left me feeling unprepared and uncertain about the material.
It seemed she might not have had a comprehensive grasp of the material and struggled to convey complex concepts effectively.

Professor Lu was extremely unhelpful throughout the course. She rarely responded to emails and seemed disinterested in helping students succeed. Overall, this was a frustrating and unproductive learning experience.
At least 3 homework every week. The homework is tedious and needs lots of time. Strict grading. Don't allow AI tools. Strongly don't recommend registering for her course.
She honestly doesn't know what she's talking about and even tells us that she knows nothing about this so we are exploring it together.
difficult to understand her English and she doesn't know how to teach.
Unclear grading criteria and bad lectures.
The worst professor I have ever met

Prof Xiao is fantastic. She acknowledges her course material isn't easy, but at the same time, does all she can to ensure you do well and understand the material. I would definitely take another class with Prof Xiao. I've grown so much as a software developer in D6, and can't wait to apply what I've learned. Other professors should take note.
The professor cares about the student. And you can learn a lot without worry about your score.

Xiao Lu is one of my favourite professor at Stevens Institute of Technology. She is very helpful even outside the class and teaches you the subject in an interesting way. Exams are very easy and if you give little attention to your project(on time submission) then you will definitely get A for this subject. I will definitely take her classes again.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: she is annoying. dont take

Lectures are mandatory. Will not let you use any sort of technology and will call you out in class in front of everybody if you do (no airpods, no phones). Lectures are very long and boring. With the amount of homework given for the class you will end up learning everything you need through the homework and the lectures will be a waste of time.

Very dry and boring lectures that make you want to fall asleep, but you can't since you get randomly called on. Somewhat helpful for the tests but not really, you have to do most of the studying yourself

Professor Henry is very knowledgeable and does a good job explaining accounting concepts, she uses a lot of real world examples in her class. She also provides outlines for notes which is really helpful. Some other accounting professors are easier, but Prof. Henry's class will prepare you better for future business classes.

Prof. Henry lecture's are dry, her tests are nothing like the homework, and she is extremely condescending and inconsiderate. She grades tests extremely harsh and does not even give partial credit if something is even just slightly wrong. Do not recommend for ACC-200, she will not teach you anything.

Decent amount of work- txtbk assignments take time. Can be a bit condescending & will call you out if she thinks you're not listening, so always pay attention. Overall, she does a great job of explaining new, abstract ideas in an understandable way & her passion for the material transfers to students, in an otherwise boring subject. Curves nicely.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Incredible professor! Still in class with her right now, it's great
Professor Henry without a doubt challenges you in her courses, but is always willing to help outside of class time.

Professor Henry was great throughout the semester. Very clear during her lectures and was interactive throughout class which engaged her students. Professor Henry is also very willing to meet outside of class, and even provided assistance in another course I was taking. Highly recommend.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Henry is a great professor with a lot of industry experience. Her class is an easy A if you do the work, and she manages to make Accounting easy to understand. She answers questions with reference to real financial statements and is always willing to help students. Take her class, study well, and you'll get an A.

Elaine Henry taught Financial Statement Analysis. She came well prepared to class everyday with useful material. She comes with great work experience at multiple big time wall street firms, what she teaches you is applicable. Professor Henry was always willing to help outside of class whenever you needed. Very Highly Reccommend. Amazing professor!

Elaine's lectures are kind of dry, but exciting when considering it's accounting. She is an expert in her field and explains concepts in ways that are easy to understand. Midterm and Final are about 65% of the final grade. I studied for two days before both and aced them. Very manageable and useful class, but don't fall too far behind with material

Tests are confusing. She is annoying. She does not care if you talk to her about fixing your grade or working with her. She has class quizzes all of the time and you have to attend basically every single class. You also have to participate. Annoying southern drawl, fake kindness, overall no fun.
